column3: 1)	" I have a plan -- not a secret plan. As a matter of fact
column4: it is the economic recovery program that we presented when I took office in 1981.  It is true that earlier
column5: working with some very prominent economists
column6: I had come up
column7: during the campaign
column8: with an economic program that I thought could rectify the great problems confronting us -- the double-digit inflation
column9: the high tax rates that I think were hurting the economy
column10: the stagflation that we were undergoing. Before even the election day
column11: something that none of those economists had even predicted had happened
column12: that the economy was so worsened that I was openly saying that what we had thought on the basis of our plan could have brought a balanced budget -- no
column13: that was no longer possible.  So
column14: the plan that we have had and that we are following is a plan that is based on growth in the economy
column15: recovery without inflation
column16: and reducing the share that the Government is taking from the gross national product
column17: which has become a drag on the economy.  Already
column18: we have a recovery that has been going on for about 21 months to the point that we can now call it an expansion. Under that
column19: this year
column20: we have seen a $21 billion reduction in the deficit from last year
column21: based mainly on the increased revenues the Government is getting without raising tax rates.  Our tax cut
column22: we think
column23: was very instrumental in bringing about this economic recovery. We have reduced inflation to about a third of what it was. The interest rates have come down about 9 or 10 points and
column24: we think
column25: must come down further. In the last 21 months
column26: more than 6 million people have gotten jobs -- there have been created new jobs for those people to where there are now 105 million civilians working
column27: where there were only 99 million before; 107
column28: if you count the military.  So
column29: we believe that as we continue to reduce the level of government spending -- the increase
column30: rate of increase in government spending
column31: which has come down from 17 to 6 percent
column32: and
column34: as the growth in the economy increases the revenues the Government gets
column35: without raising taxes
column36: those two lines will meet. And when they meet
column37: that is a balanced budget.

column1: The deficit is the result of excessive government spending. I do not
column3: take seriously the Congressional Budget Office projections
column4: because they have been wrong on virtually all of them
column5: including the fact that our recovery wasn't going to take place to begin with. But it has taken place.  But
column6: as I said
column7: we have the rate of increase in government spending down to 6 percent. If the rate of increase in government spending can be held at 5 percent -- we're not far from there -- by 1989 that would have reduced the budget deficits down to a $30 or $40 billion level. At the same time
column8: if we can have a 4-percent recovery continue through that same period of time
column9: that will mean -- without an increase in tax rates -- that will mean $400 billion more in government revenues. And so
column10: I think that the lines can meet.  Actually
column11: in constant dollars
column12: in the domestic side of the budget
column13: there has been no spending increase in the 4 years that we have been here.

column1: One of the key tests of leadership is whether one sees clearly the nature of the problems confronted by our nation. And perhaps the dominant domestic issue of our times is what do we do about these enormous deficits. I respect the President; I respect the Presidency
column2: and I think he knows that. But the fact of it is
column3: every estimate by this administration about the size of the deficit has been off by billions and billions of dollars. As a matter of fact
column4: over 4 years
column5: they've missed the mark by nearly $600 billion. We were told we would have a balanced budget in 1983. It was $200 billion deficit instead. And now we have a major question facing the American people as to whether we'll deal with this deficit and get it down for the sake of a healthy recovery.  Virtually every economic analysis that I've heard of
column6: including the distinguished Congressional Budget Office
column7: which is respected by
column8: I think
column9: almost everyone
column10: says that even with historically high levels of economic growth
column11: we will suffer a $263 billion deficit. In other words
column12: it doesn't converge as the President suggests. It gets larger even with growth.  What that means is that we will continue to have devastating problems with foreign trade. This is the worst trade year in American history by far. Our rural and farm friends will have continued devastation. Real interest rates -- the real cost of interest -- will remain very
column13: very high
column14: and many economists are predicting that we're moving into a period of very slow growth because the economy is tapering off and may be a recession. I get it down to a level below 2 percent of gross national product with a policy that's fair. I've stood up and told the American people that I think it's a real problem
column15: that it can destroy long-term economic growth
column16: and I've told you what I think should be done.  I think this is a test of leadership
column17: and I think the American people know the difference.

column2: and I proposed over a hundred billion dollars in cuts in Federal spending over 4 years
column3: but I am not going to cut it out of Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and things -- [applause] -- that people need. These people depend upon all of us for the little security that they have
column4: and I'm not going to do it that way. The rate of defense spending increase can be slowed. Certainly we can find a coffeepot that costs something less than $7
column5: 000. And there are other ways of squeezing this budget without constantly picking on our senior citizens and the most vulnerable in American life. And that's why the Congress
column6: including the Republicans
column7: have not gone along with the President's recommendations.

column1: Yes. I don't believe that Mr. Mondale has a plan for balancing the budget; he has a plan for raising taxes. And
column3: the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history took place 1977. And for the 5 years previous to our taking office
column4: taxes doubled in the United States
column5: and the budgets increased $318 billion. So
column6: there is no ratio between taxing and balancing a budget. Whether you borrow the money or whether you simply tax it away from the people
column7: you're taking the same amount of money out of the private sector
column8: unless and until you bring down government's share of what it is taking. With regard to Social Security
column9: I hope there'll be more time than just this minute to mention that
column10: but I will say this: A President should never say ""never.'' But I'm going to violate that rule and say ""never.'' I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.

column2: that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits. And of course
column3: what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation
column4: cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security
column5: removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college. Everybody remembers that; people know what happened. There's a difference. I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life
column6: and I will do it as President of the United States.

column10: but I will say this: A President should never say ""never.'' But I'm going to violate that rule and say ""never.'' I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.

column2: that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits. And of course
column3: what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation
column4: cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security
column5: removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college. Everybody remembers that; people know what happened. There's a difference. I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life
column6: and I will do it as President of the United States.

column1: The deficit is the result of excessive government spending. I do not
column3: take seriously the Congressional Budget Office projections
column4: because they have been wrong on virtually all of them
column5: including the fact that our recovery wasn't going to take place to begin with. But it has taken place.  But
column6: as I said
column7: we have the rate of increase in government spending down to 6 percent. If the rate of increase in government spending can be held at 5 percent -- we're not far from there -- by 1989 that would have reduced the budget deficits down to a $30 or $40 billion level. At the same time
column8: if we can have a 4-percent recovery continue through that same period of time
column9: that will mean -- without an increase in tax rates -- that will mean $400 billion more in government revenues. And so
column10: I think that the lines can meet.  Actually
column11: in constant dollars
column12: in the domestic side of the budget
column13: there has been no spending increase in the 4 years that we have been here.

column1: One of the key tests of leadership is whether one sees clearly the nature of the problems confronted by our nation. And perhaps the dominant domestic issue of our times is what do we do about these enormous deficits. I respect the President; I respect the Presidency
column2: and I think he knows that. But the fact of it is
column3: every estimate by this administration about the size of the deficit has been off by billions and billions of dollars. As a matter of fact
column4: over 4 years
column5: they've missed the mark by nearly $600 billion. We were told we would have a balanced budget in 1983. It was $200 billion deficit instead. And now we have a major question facing the American people as to whether we'll deal with this deficit and get it down for the sake of a healthy recovery.  Virtually every economic analysis that I've heard of
column6: including the distinguished Congressional Budget Office
column7: which is respected by
column8: I think
column9: almost everyone
column10: says that even with historically high levels of economic growth
column11: we will suffer a $263 billion deficit. In other words
column12: it doesn't converge as the President suggests. It gets larger even with growth.  What that means is that we will continue to have devastating problems with foreign trade. This is the worst trade year in American history by far. Our rural and farm friends will have continued devastation. Real interest rates -- the real cost of interest -- will remain very
column13: very high
column14: and many economists are predicting that we're moving into a period of very slow growth because the economy is tapering off and may be a recession. I get it down to a level below 2 percent of gross national product with a policy that's fair. I've stood up and told the American people that I think it's a real problem
column15: that it can destroy long-term economic growth
column16: and I've told you what I think should be done.  I think this is a test of leadership
column17: and I think the American people know the difference.

column2: and I proposed over a hundred billion dollars in cuts in Federal spending over 4 years
column3: but I am not going to cut it out of Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and things -- [applause] -- that people need. These people depend upon all of us for the little security that they have
column4: and I'm not going to do it that way. The rate of defense spending increase can be slowed. Certainly we can find a coffeepot that costs something less than $7
column5: 000. And there are other ways of squeezing this budget without constantly picking on our senior citizens and the most vulnerable in American life. And that's why the Congress
column6: including the Republicans
column7: have not gone along with the President's recommendations.

column1: Yes. I don't believe that Mr. Mondale has a plan for balancing the budget; he has a plan for raising taxes. And
column3: the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history took place 1977. And for the 5 years previous to our taking office
column4: taxes doubled in the United States
column5: and the budgets increased $318 billion. So
column6: there is no ratio between taxing and balancing a budget. Whether you borrow the money or whether you simply tax it away from the people
column7: you're taking the same amount of money out of the private sector
column8: unless and until you bring down government's share of what it is taking. With regard to Social Security
column9: I hope there'll be more time than just this minute to mention that
column10: but I will say this: A President should never say ""never.'' But I'm going to violate that rule and say ""never.'' I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.

column2: that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits. And of course
column3: what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation
column4: cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security
column5: removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college. Everybody remembers that; people know what happened. There's a difference. I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life
column6: and I will do it as President of the United States.

column1: The deficit is the result of excessive government spending. I do not
column3: take seriously the Congressional Budget Office projections
column4: because they have been wrong on virtually all of them
column5: including the fact that our recovery wasn't going to take place to begin with. But it has taken place.  But
column6: as I said
column7: we have the rate of increase in government spending down to 6 percent. If the rate of increase in government spending can be held at 5 percent -- we're not far from there -- by 1989 that would have reduced the budget deficits down to a $30 or $40 billion level. At the same time
column8: if we can have a 4-percent recovery continue through that same period of time
column9: that will mean -- without an increase in tax rates -- that will mean $400 billion more in government revenues. And so
column10: I think that the lines can meet.  Actually
column11: in constant dollars
column12: in the domestic side of the budget
column13: there has been no spending increase in the 4 years that we have been here.

column1: One of the key tests of leadership is whether one sees clearly the nature of the problems confronted by our nation. And perhaps the dominant domestic issue of our times is what do we do about these enormous deficits. I respect the President; I respect the Presidency
column2: and I think he knows that. But the fact of it is
column3: every estimate by this administration about the size of the deficit has been off by billions and billions of dollars. As a matter of fact
column4: over 4 years
column5: they've missed the mark by nearly $600 billion. We were told we would have a balanced budget in 1983. It was $200 billion deficit instead. And now we have a major question facing the American people as to whether we'll deal with this deficit and get it down for the sake of a healthy recovery.  Virtually every economic analysis that I've heard of
column6: including the distinguished Congressional Budget Office
column7: which is respected by
column8: I think
column9: almost everyone
column10: says that even with historically high levels of economic growth
column11: we will suffer a $263 billion deficit. In other words
column12: it doesn't converge as the President suggests. It gets larger even with growth.  What that means is that we will continue to have devastating problems with foreign trade. This is the worst trade year in American history by far. Our rural and farm friends will have continued devastation. Real interest rates -- the real cost of interest -- will remain very
column13: very high
column14: and many economists are predicting that we're moving into a period of very slow growth because the economy is tapering off and may be a recession. I get it down to a level below 2 percent of gross national product with a policy that's fair. I've stood up and told the American people that I think it's a real problem
column15: that it can destroy long-term economic growth
column16: and I've told you what I think should be done.  I think this is a test of leadership
column17: and I think the American people know the difference.

column2: and I proposed over a hundred billion dollars in cuts in Federal spending over 4 years
column3: but I am not going to cut it out of Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and things -- [applause] -- that people need. These people depend upon all of us for the little security that they have
column4: and I'm not going to do it that way. The rate of defense spending increase can be slowed. Certainly we can find a coffeepot that costs something less than $7
column5: 000. And there are other ways of squeezing this budget without constantly picking on our senior citizens and the most vulnerable in American life. And that's why the Congress
column6: including the Republicans
column7: have not gone along with the President's recommendations.

column1: Yes. I don't believe that Mr. Mondale has a plan for balancing the budget; he has a plan for raising taxes. And
column3: the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history took place 1977. And for the 5 years previous to our taking office
column4: taxes doubled in the United States
column5: and the budgets increased $318 billion. So
column6: there is no ratio between taxing and balancing a budget. Whether you borrow the money or whether you simply tax it away from the people
column7: you're taking the same amount of money out of the private sector
column8: unless and until you bring down government's share of what it is taking. With regard to Social Security
column9: I hope there'll be more time than just this minute to mention that
column10: but I will say this: A President should never say ""never.'' But I'm going to violate that rule and say ""never.'' I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.

column2: that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits. And of course
column3: what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation
column4: cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security
column5: removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college. Everybody remembers that; people know what happened. There's a difference. I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life
column6: and I will do it as President of the United States.

column3: 1)	" I have a plan -- not a secret plan. As a matter of fact
column4: it is the economic recovery program that we presented when I took office in 1981.  It is true that earlier
column5: working with some very prominent economists
column6: I had come up
column7: during the campaign
column8: with an economic program that I thought could rectify the great problems confronting us -- the double-digit inflation
column9: the high tax rates that I think were hurting the economy
column10: the stagflation that we were undergoing. Before even the election day
column11: something that none of those economists had even predicted had happened
column12: that the economy was so worsened that I was openly saying that what we had thought on the basis of our plan could have brought a balanced budget -- no
column13: that was no longer possible.  So
column14: the plan that we have had and that we are following is a plan that is based on growth in the economy
column15: recovery without inflation
column16: and reducing the share that the Government is taking from the gross national product
column17: which has become a drag on the economy.  Already
column18: we have a recovery that has been going on for about 21 months to the point that we can now call it an expansion. Under that
column19: this year
column20: we have seen a $21 billion reduction in the deficit from last year
column21: based mainly on the increased revenues the Government is getting without raising tax rates.  Our tax cut
column22: we think
column23: was very instrumental in bringing about this economic recovery. We have reduced inflation to about a third of what it was. The interest rates have come down about 9 or 10 points and
column24: we think
column25: must come down further. In the last 21 months
column26: more than 6 million people have gotten jobs -- there have been created new jobs for those people to where there are now 105 million civilians working
column27: where there were only 99 million before; 107
column28: if you count the military.  So
column29: we believe that as we continue to reduce the level of government spending -- the increase
column30: rate of increase in government spending
column31: which has come down from 17 to 6 percent
column32: and
column34: as the growth in the economy increases the revenues the Government gets
column35: without raising taxes
column36: those two lines will meet. And when they meet
column37: that is a balanced budget.

column1: The deficit is the result of excessive government spending. I do not
column3: take seriously the Congressional Budget Office projections
column4: because they have been wrong on virtually all of them
column5: including the fact that our recovery wasn't going to take place to begin with. But it has taken place.  But
column6: as I said
column7: we have the rate of increase in government spending down to 6 percent. If the rate of increase in government spending can be held at 5 percent -- we're not far from there -- by 1989 that would have reduced the budget deficits down to a $30 or $40 billion level. At the same time
column8: if we can have a 4-percent recovery continue through that same period of time
column9: that will mean -- without an increase in tax rates -- that will mean $400 billion more in government revenues. And so
column10: I think that the lines can meet.  Actually
column11: in constant dollars
column12: in the domestic side of the budget
column13: there has been no spending increase in the 4 years that we have been here.

column1: One of the key tests of leadership is whether one sees clearly the nature of the problems confronted by our nation. And perhaps the dominant domestic issue of our times is what do we do about these enormous deficits. I respect the President; I respect the Presidency
column2: and I think he knows that. But the fact of it is
column3: every estimate by this administration about the size of the deficit has been off by billions and billions of dollars. As a matter of fact
column4: over 4 years
column5: they've missed the mark by nearly $600 billion. We were told we would have a balanced budget in 1983. It was $200 billion deficit instead. And now we have a major question facing the American people as to whether we'll deal with this deficit and get it down for the sake of a healthy recovery.  Virtually every economic analysis that I've heard of
column6: including the distinguished Congressional Budget Office
column7: which is respected by
column8: I think
column9: almost everyone
column10: says that even with historically high levels of economic growth
column11: we will suffer a $263 billion deficit. In other words
column12: it doesn't converge as the President suggests. It gets larger even with growth.  What that means is that we will continue to have devastating problems with foreign trade. This is the worst trade year in American history by far. Our rural and farm friends will have continued devastation. Real interest rates -- the real cost of interest -- will remain very
column13: very high
column14: and many economists are predicting that we're moving into a period of very slow growth because the economy is tapering off and may be a recession. I get it down to a level below 2 percent of gross national product with a policy that's fair. I've stood up and told the American people that I think it's a real problem
column15: that it can destroy long-term economic growth
column16: and I've told you what I think should be done.  I think this is a test of leadership
column17: and I think the American people know the difference.

column2: and I proposed over a hundred billion dollars in cuts in Federal spending over 4 years
column3: but I am not going to cut it out of Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and things -- [applause] -- that people need. These people depend upon all of us for the little security that they have
column4: and I'm not going to do it that way. The rate of defense spending increase can be slowed. Certainly we can find a coffeepot that costs something less than $7
column5: 000. And there are other ways of squeezing this budget without constantly picking on our senior citizens and the most vulnerable in American life. And that's why the Congress
column6: including the Republicans
column7: have not gone along with the President's recommendations.

column1: Yes. I don't believe that Mr. Mondale has a plan for balancing the budget; he has a plan for raising taxes. And
column3: the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history took place 1977. And for the 5 years previous to our taking office
column4: taxes doubled in the United States
column5: and the budgets increased $318 billion. So
column6: there is no ratio between taxing and balancing a budget. Whether you borrow the money or whether you simply tax it away from the people
column7: you're taking the same amount of money out of the private sector
column8: unless and until you bring down government's share of what it is taking. With regard to Social Security
column9: I hope there'll be more time than just this minute to mention that
column10: but I will say this: A President should never say ""never.'' But I'm going to violate that rule and say ""never.'' I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.

column2: that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits. And of course
column3: what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation
column4: cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security
column5: removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college. Everybody remembers that; people know what happened. There's a difference. I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life
column6: and I will do it as President of the United States.

column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think the first answer this evening suggests exactly what I'm saying. There is no question that we face this massive deficit
column6: and almost everybody agrees unless we get it down
column7: the chances for long-term
column8: healthy growth are nil. And it's also unfair to dump these tremendous bills on our children. The President says it will disappear overnight because of some reason. No one else believes that's the case. I do
column9: and I'm standing up to the issue with an answer that's fair. I think that's what leadership is all about. There's a difference between being a quarterback and a cheerleader
column10: and when there's a real problem
column11: a President must confront it.  What I was referring to
column12: of course
column13: in the comment that you referred to was the situation in Lebanon. Now
column14: for three occasions
column15: one after another
column16: our Embassies were assaulted in the same way by a truck with demolitions. The first time -- and I did not criticize the President
column17: because these things can happen -- once
column18: and sometimes twice -- the second time the barracks in Lebanon were assaulted
column19: as we all remember. There was two or three commission reports
column20: recommendations by the CIA
column21: the State Department
column22: and the others
column23: and the third time there was even a warning from the terrorists themselves.  Now
column24: I believe that a President must command that White House and those who work for him. It's the toughest job on Earth
column25: and you must master the facts and insist that things that must be done are done. I believe that the way in which I will approach the Presidency is what's needed
column26: because all my life that has been the way in which I have sought to lead. And that's why in this campaign I'm telling you exactly what I want to do. I am answering your questions. I am trying to provide leadership now
column27: before the election
column28: so that the American people can participate in that decision.

column2: I think we're getting better all the time. And I think tonight
column3: as we contrast for the first time our differing approach to government
column4: to values
column5: to the leadership in this country
column6: I think as this debate goes forward
column7: the American people will have for the first time a chance to weigh the two of us against each other. And I think
column8: as a part of that process
column9: what I am trying to say will come across
column10: and that is that we must lead
column11: we must command
column12: we must direct
column13: and a President must see it like it is. He must stand for the values of decency that the American people stand for
column14: and he must use the power of the White House to try to control these nuclear weapons and lead this world toward a safer world.

column3: let me suggest my own idea about the leadership factor
column4: since you've asked it. And
column5: incidentally
column6: I might say that with regard to the 25-percent cut in Social Security -- before I get to the answer to your question -- the only 25-percent cut that I know of was accompanying that huge 1977 tax increase
column7: was a cut of 25 percent in the benefits for every American who was born after 1916. Now
column8: leadership. First of all
column9: I think you must have some principles you believe in. In mine
column10: I happen to believe in the people and believe that the people are supposed to be dominant in our society -- that they
column11: not government
column12: are to have control of their own affairs to the greatest extent possible
column13: with an orderly society.  Now
column14: having that
column15: I think also that in leadership -- well
column16: I believe that you find people
column17: positions such as I'm in who have the talent and ability to do the things that are needed in the various departments of government. I don't believe that a leader should be spending his time in the Oval Office deciding who's going to play tennis on the White House court. And you let those people go with the guidelines of overall policy
column18: not looking over their shoulder and nitpicking the manner in which they go at the job. You are ultimately responsible
column19: however
column20: for that job.  But I also believe something else about that. I believe that -- and when I became Governor of California
column21: I started this
column22: and I continue it in this office -- that any issue that comes before me
column23: I have instructed Cabinet members and staff they are not to bring up any of the political ramifications that might surround the issue. I don't want to hear them. I want to hear only arguments as to whether it is good or bad for the people -- is it morally right? And on that basis and that basis alone
column24: we make a decision on every issue.  Now
column25: with regard to my feeling about why I thought that his record bespoke his possible taking us back to the same things that we knew under the previous administration
column26: his record is that he spoke in praise of deficits several times
column27: said they weren't to be abhorred -- that
column28: as a matter of fact
column29: he at one time said he wished the deficit could be doubled
column30: because they stimulate the economy and helped reduce unemployment.

column1: Our policy was not to cut subsidies. We have believed in partnership
column2: and that was an example of a partnership between
column3: not only local government and the Federal Government but also between the private sector that built that particular structure. And this is what we've been trying to do
column4: is involve the Federal Government in such partnerships. We are today subsidizing housing for more than 10 million people
column5: and we're going to continue along that line. We have no thought of throwing people out into the snow
column6: whether because of age or need. We have preserved the safety net for the people with true need in this country
column7: and it has been pure demagoguery that we have in some way shut off all the charitable programs or many of them for the people who have real need. The safety net is there
column8: and we're taking care of more people than has ever been taken care of before by any administration in this country.

column2: I guess I'm reminded a little bit of what Will Rogers once said about Hoover. He said
column3: ""It's not what he doesn't know that bothers me; it's what he knows for sure that just ain't so.'' [Laughter] The fact of it is: The President's budget sought to cut Social Security by 25 percent. It's not an opinion; it's a fact. And when the President was asked the other day
column4: ""What do you want to cut in the budget?''
column5: he said
column6: ""Cut those things I asked for but didn't get.'' That's Social Security and Medicare. The second fact is that the housing unit for senior citizens that the President dedicated in Buffalo was only made possible through a Federal assistance program for senior citizens that the President's budget sought to terminate. So
column7: if he'd had his way
column8: there wouldn't have been any housing project there at all. This administration has taken a meat cleaver out
column9: in terms of Federal-assisted housing
column10: and the record is there. We have to see the facts before we can draw conclusions.

column2: let me just respond with regard to Social Security. When we took office
column3: we discovered that the program that the Carter-Mondale administration had said would solve the fiscal problems of Social Security for the next 50 years wouldn't solve them for 5. Social Security was due to go bankrupt before 1983. Any proposals that I made at that time were at the request of the chairman
column4: a Democrat
column5: of one of the leading committees
column6: who said we have to do something before the program goes broke and the checks bounce. And so
column7: we made a proposal. And then in 1982
column8: they used that proposal in a demagogic fashion for the 1982 campaign. And 3 days after the election in 1982
column9: they came to us and said
column10: Social Security
column11: we know
column12: is broke. Indeed
column13: we had to borrow $17 billion to pay the checks. And then I asked for a bipartisan commission
column14: which I'd asked for from the beginning
column15: to sit down and work out a solution.  And so
column16: the whole matter of what to do with Social Security has been resolved by bipartisan legislation
column17: and it is on a sound basis now for as far as you can see into the next century.

column4: first of all
column5: I think the first answer this evening suggests exactly what I'm saying. There is no question that we face this massive deficit
column6: and almost everybody agrees unless we get it down
column7: the chances for long-term
column8: healthy growth are nil. And it's also unfair to dump these tremendous bills on our children. The President says it will disappear overnight because of some reason. No one else believes that's the case. I do
column9: and I'm standing up to the issue with an answer that's fair. I think that's what leadership is all about. There's a difference between being a quarterback and a cheerleader
column10: and when there's a real problem
column11: a President must confront it.  What I was referring to
column12: of course
column13: in the comment that you referred to was the situation in Lebanon. Now
column14: for three occasions
column15: one after another
column16: our Embassies were assaulted in the same way by a truck with demolitions. The first time -- and I did not criticize the President
column17: because these things can happen -- once
column18: and sometimes twice -- the second time the barracks in Lebanon were assaulted
column19: as we all remember. There was two or three commission reports
column20: recommendations by the CIA
column21: the State Department
column22: and the others
column23: and the third time there was even a warning from the terrorists themselves.  Now
column24: I believe that a President must command that White House and those who work for him. It's the toughest job on Earth
column25: and you must master the facts and insist that things that must be done are done. I believe that the way in which I will approach the Presidency is what's needed
column26: because all my life that has been the way in which I have sought to lead. And that's why in this campaign I'm telling you exactly what I want to do. I am answering your questions. I am trying to provide leadership now
column27: before the election
column28: so that the American people can participate in that decision.

column2: I think we're getting better all the time. And I think tonight
column3: as we contrast for the first time our differing approach to government
column4: to values
column5: to the leadership in this country
column6: I think as this debate goes forward
column7: the American people will have for the first time a chance to weigh the two of us against each other. And I think
column8: as a part of that process
column9: what I am trying to say will come across
column10: and that is that we must lead
column11: we must command
column12: we must direct
column13: and a President must see it like it is. He must stand for the values of decency that the American people stand for
column14: and he must use the power of the White House to try to control these nuclear weapons and lead this world toward a safer world.

column3: let me suggest my own idea about the leadership factor
column4: since you've asked it. And
column5: incidentally
column6: I might say that with regard to the 25-percent cut in Social Security -- before I get to the answer to your question -- the only 25-percent cut that I know of was accompanying that huge 1977 tax increase
column7: was a cut of 25 percent in the benefits for every American who was born after 1916. Now
column8: leadership. First of all
column9: I think you must have some principles you believe in. In mine

column11: not government

column13: with an orderly society.  Now
column14: having that
column15: I think also that in leadership -- well
column16: I believe that you find people
column17: positions such as I'm in who have the talent and ability to do the things that are needed in the various departments of government. I don't believe that a leader should be spending his time in the Oval Office deciding who's going to play tennis on the White House court. And you let those people go with the guidelines of overall policy
column18: not looking over their shoulder and nitpicking the manner in which they go at the job. You are ultimately responsible
column19: however
column20: for that job.  But I also believe something else about that. I believe that -- and when I became Governor of California
column21: I started this
column22: and I continue it in this office -- that any issue that comes before me
column23: I have instructed Cabinet members and staff they are not to bring up any of the political ramifications that might surround the issue. I don't want to hear them. I want to hear only arguments as to whether it is good or bad for the people -- is it morally right? And on that basis and that basis alone
column24: we make a decision on every issue.  Now
column25: with regard to my feeling about why I thought that his record bespoke his possible taking us back to the same things that we knew under the previous administration
column26: his record is that he spoke in praise of deficits several times

column1: Our policy was not to cut subsidies. We have believed in partnership
column2: and that was an example of a partnership between
column3: not only local government and the Federal Government but also between the private sector that built that particular structure. And this is what we've been trying to do
column4: is involve the Federal Government in such partnerships. We are today subsidizing housing for more than 10 million people
column5: and we're going to continue along that line. We have no thought of throwing people out into the snow
column6: whether because of age or need. We have preserved the safety net for the people with true need in this country
column7: and it has been pure demagoguery that we have in some way shut off all the charitable programs or many of them for the people who have real need. The safety net is there
column8: and we're taking care of more people than has ever been taken care of before by any administration in this country.

column2: I guess I'm reminded a little bit of what Will Rogers once said about Hoover. He said
column3: ""It's not what he doesn't know that bothers me; it's what he knows for sure that just ain't so.'' [Laughter] The fact of it is: The President's budget sought to cut Social Security by 25 percent. It's not an opinion; it's a fact. And when the President was asked the other day
column4: ""What do you want to cut in the budget?''
column5: he said
column6: ""Cut those things I asked for but didn't get.'' That's Social Security and Medicare. The second fact is that the housing unit for senior citizens that the President dedicated in Buffalo was only made possible through a Federal assistance program for senior citizens that the President's budget sought to terminate. So
column7: if he'd had his way
column8: there wouldn't have been any housing project there at all. This administration has taken a meat cleaver out
column9: in terms of Federal-assisted housing
column10: and the record is there. We have to see the facts before we can draw conclusions.

column2: let me just respond with regard to Social Security. When we took office
column3: we discovered that the program that the Carter-Mondale administration had said would solve the fiscal problems of Social Security for the next 50 years wouldn't solve them for 5. Social Security was due to go bankrupt before 1983. Any proposals that I made at that time were at the request of the chairman
column4: a Democrat
column5: of one of the leading committees
column6: who said we have to do something before the program goes broke and the checks bounce. And so
column7: we made a proposal. And then in 1982
column8: they used that proposal in a demagogic fashion for the 1982 campaign. And 3 days after the election in 1982
column9: they came to us and said
column10: Social Security
column11: we know
column12: is broke. Indeed
column13: we had to borrow $17 billion to pay the checks. And then I asked for a bipartisan commission
column14: which I'd asked for from the beginning
column15: to sit down and work out a solution.  And so
column16: the whole matter of what to do with Social Security has been resolved by bipartisan legislation
column17: and it is on a sound basis now for as far as you can see into the next century.

column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think the first answer this evening suggests exactly what I'm saying. There is no question that we face this massive deficit
column6: and almost everybody agrees unless we get it down
column7: the chances for long-term
column8: healthy growth are nil. And it's also unfair to dump these tremendous bills on our children. The President says it will disappear overnight because of some reason. No one else believes that's the case. I do
column9: and I'm standing up to the issue with an answer that's fair. I think that's what leadership is all about. There's a difference between being a quarterback and a cheerleader
column10: and when there's a real problem
column11: a President must confront it.  What I was referring to
column12: of course
column13: in the comment that you referred to was the situation in Lebanon. Now
column14: for three occasions
column15: one after another
column16: our Embassies were assaulted in the same way by a truck with demolitions. The first time -- and I did not criticize the President
column17: because these things can happen -- once
column18: and sometimes twice -- the second time the barracks in Lebanon were assaulted
column19: as we all remember. There was two or three commission reports
column20: recommendations by the CIA
column21: the State Department
column22: and the others
column23: and the third time there was even a warning from the terrorists themselves.  Now
column24: I believe that a President must command that White House and those who work for him. It's the toughest job on Earth
column25: and you must master the facts and insist that things that must be done are done. I believe that the way in which I will approach the Presidency is what's needed
column26: because all my life that has been the way in which I have sought to lead. And that's why in this campaign I'm telling you exactly what I want to do. I am answering your questions. I am trying to provide leadership now
column27: before the election
column28: so that the American people can participate in that decision.

column2: I think we're getting better all the time. And I think tonight
column3: as we contrast for the first time our differing approach to government
column4: to values
column5: to the leadership in this country
column6: I think as this debate goes forward
column7: the American people will have for the first time a chance to weigh the two of us against each other. And I think
column8: as a part of that process
column9: what I am trying to say will come across
column10: and that is that we must lead
column11: we must command
column12: we must direct
column13: and a President must see it like it is. He must stand for the values of decency that the American people stand for
column14: and he must use the power of the White House to try to control these nuclear weapons and lead this world toward a safer world.

column3: let me suggest my own idea about the leadership factor
column4: since you've asked it. And
column5: incidentally
column6: I might say that with regard to the 25-percent cut in Social Security -- before I get to the answer to your question -- the only 25-percent cut that I know of was accompanying that huge 1977 tax increase
column7: was a cut of 25 percent in the benefits for every American who was born after 1916. Now
column8: leadership. First of all
column9: I think you must have some principles you believe in. In mine
column10: I happen to believe in the people and believe that the people are supposed to be dominant in our society -- that they
column11: not government
column12: are to have control of their own affairs to the greatest extent possible
column13: with an orderly society.  Now
column14: having that
column15: I think also that in leadership -- well
column16: I believe that you find people
column17: positions such as I'm in who have the talent and ability to do the things that are needed in the various departments of government. I don't believe that a leader should be spending his time in the Oval Office deciding who's going to play tennis on the White House court. And you let those people go with the guidelines of overall policy
column18: not looking over their shoulder and nitpicking the manner in which they go at the job. You are ultimately responsible
column19: however
column20: for that job.  But I also believe something else about that. I believe that -- and when I became Governor of California
column21: I started this
column22: and I continue it in this office -- that any issue that comes before me
column23: I have instructed Cabinet members and staff they are not to bring up any of the political ramifications that might surround the issue. I don't want to hear them. I want to hear only arguments as to whether it is good or bad for the people -- is it morally right? And on that basis and that basis alone
column24: we make a decision on every issue.  Now
column25: with regard to my feeling about why I thought that his record bespoke his possible taking us back to the same things that we knew under the previous administration
column26: his record is that he spoke in praise of deficits several times
column27: said they weren't to be abhorred -- that
column28: as a matter of fact
column29: he at one time said he wished the deficit could be doubled
column30: because they stimulate the economy and helped reduce unemployment.

column1: Our policy was not to cut subsidies. We have believed in partnership
column2: and that was an example of a partnership between
column3: not only local government and the Federal Government but also between the private sector that built that particular structure. And this is what we've been trying to do
column4: is involve the Federal Government in such partnerships. We are today subsidizing housing for more than 10 million people
column5: and we're going to continue along that line. We have no thought of throwing people out into the snow
column6: whether because of age or need. We have preserved the safety net for the people with true need in this country
column7: and it has been pure demagoguery that we have in some way shut off all the charitable programs or many of them for the people who have real need. The safety net is there
column8: and we're taking care of more people than has ever been taken care of before by any administration in this country.

column2: I guess I'm reminded a little bit of what Will Rogers once said about Hoover. He said
column3: ""It's not what he doesn't know that bothers me; it's what he knows for sure that just ain't so.'' [Laughter] The fact of it is: The President's budget sought to cut Social Security by 25 percent. It's not an opinion; it's a fact. And when the President was asked the other day
column4: ""What do you want to cut in the budget?''
column5: he said
column6: ""Cut those things I asked for but didn't get.'' That's Social Security and Medicare. The second fact is that the housing unit for senior citizens that the President dedicated in Buffalo was only made possible through a Federal assistance program for senior citizens that the President's budget sought to terminate. So
column7: if he'd had his way
column8: there wouldn't have been any housing project there at all. This administration has taken a meat cleaver out
column9: in terms of Federal-assisted housing
column10: and the record is there. We have to see the facts before we can draw conclusions.

column2: let me just respond with regard to Social Security. When we took office
column3: we discovered that the program that the Carter-Mondale administration had said would solve the fiscal problems of Social Security for the next 50 years wouldn't solve them for 5. Social Security was due to go bankrupt before 1983. Any proposals that I made at that time were at the request of the chairman
column4: a Democrat
column5: of one of the leading committees
column6: who said we have to do something before the program goes broke and the checks bounce. And so
column7: we made a proposal. And then in 1982
column8: they used that proposal in a demagogic fashion for the 1982 campaign. And 3 days after the election in 1982
column9: they came to us and said
column10: Social Security
column11: we know
column12: is broke. Indeed
column13: we had to borrow $17 billion to pay the checks. And then I asked for a bipartisan commission
column14: which I'd asked for from the beginning
column15: to sit down and work out a solution.  And so
column16: the whole matter of what to do with Social Security has been resolved by bipartisan legislation
column17: and it is on a sound basis now for as far as you can see into the next century.

chances for longterm, healthy growth are nil', 'And its also unfair to dump these tremendous bills on our children', 'The President says it will disappear overnight because of some reason', 'No one else believes thats the case', 'I do, and Im standing up to the issue with an answer thats fair', 'I think thats what leadership is all about', 'Theres a difference between being a quarterback and a occasions, one after another, our Embassies were assaulted in the same way by a truck with demolitions', 'The first time  and I did not criticize the President, because these things can happen  once, and sometimes twice  the second time the barracks in Lebanon were assaulted, as we all remember', 'There was two or three commission reports, recommendations by the CIA, the State Department, and the others, and the third time there was even a warning from the terrorists themselves', 'Now, I believe that a President must command that White House and those who work for him', 'Its the toughest job on Earth, and you must master the facts and insist that things that must be done are done', 'I believe that the way in which I will approach the Presidency is whats needed, because all my life that has been the way in which I have sought to lead', 'And thats why in this campaign Im telling you exactly what I want to do', 'I am answering your questions', 'I am trying to provide leadership now, before the election, so that the American people can participate in that decision', 'Well, I think were getting better all the time', 'And I think tonight, as we contrast for the first time our against each other', 'And I think, as a part of that process, what I am trying to say will come across, and that is that we must lead, we must command, we must direct, and a President must see it like it is', 'He must stand for the values of decency that the American people stand for, and he must use the power of the White House to try to control these nuclear weapons and lead this world toward a safer world', 'Well, whether he does or not, let me suggest my own idea about the leadership factor, since youve asked it', 'And, incidentally, I might say that with regard to the 25percent cut in Social Security  before I get to the answer to your question  the only 25percent cut that I know of was accompanying that huge 1977 tax increase, was a cut of 25 percent in the benefits for every American who was born after 1916', 'Now, leadership', 'First of all, I think you must have some principles you believe in', 'In mine, I happen to believe in the people and believe that the people are supposed to be dominant in our society  that they, not government, are to have control of their own affairs to the greatest extent possible, with an orderly society', 'Now, having that, I think also that in leadership  well, I believe that you find people, positions such as Im in who have the talent and ability to do the things that are needed in the various departments of government', 'I dont believe that a leader should be spending his time in the Oval Office deciding whos going to play tennis on the White House court', 'And you let those people go with the guidelines of overall policy, to bring up any of the political ramifications that might surround the issue', 'I dont want to hear them', 'I want to hear only arguments as to whether it is good or bad for the people  is it morally right?', 'And on that basis and that basis alone, we make a decision on every issue', 'Now, with regard to my feeling about why I thought that his record bespoke his possible taking us back to the same things that we knew under the previous administration, his record is that he spoke in praise of deficits several times, said they werent to be abhorred  that, as a matter of fact, he at one time said he wished the deficit could be doubled, because they stimulate the economy and helped reduce unemployment', 'Our policy was not to cut subsidies', 'We have believed in partnership, and that was an example of a partnership between, not only local government and the Federal Government but also between the private sector that built that particular structure', 'And this is what weve been trying to do, is involve the Federal Government in such partnerships', 'We are today subsidizing housing for more than 10 million people, and were going to continue along that line', 'We have no thought of throwing people out into the snow, whether because of age or need', 'We have preserved the safety net for the people with true need in this country, and it has been pure demagoguery that we have in by any administration in this country', 'Well, I guess Im reminded a little bit of what Will Rogers once said about Hoover', 'He said, Its not what he doesnt know that bothers me; its what he knows citizens that the President dedicated in Buffalo was only made possible through a Federal assistance program for senior citizens that the Presidents budget sought to terminate', 'So, if hed had his way, there wouldnt have been any housing project there at all', 'This administration has taken a meat cleaver out, in terms of Federalassisted housing, and the record is there', 'We have to see the facts before we can draw conclusions', 'Well, let me just respond with regard to Social Security', 'When we took office, we discovered that the program that the CarterMondale administration had said would solve the fiscal problems of Social Security for the next 50 years wouldnt solve them for 5', 'Social Security was due to go bankrupt before 1983', 'Any proposals that I made at that time were at the request of the chairman, a Democrat, of one of the leading committees, who said we have to do something before the program goes broke and the checks bounce', 'And so, we made a proposal', 'And then in 1982, they used that proposal in a demagogic fashion for the 1982 campaign', 'And 3 days after the election in 1982, they came to us and said, Social Security, we know, is broke', 'Indeed, we had to borrow $17 billion to pay the checks', 'And then I asked for a bipartisan commission, which Id asked for from the beginning, to sit down and work out a solution', 'And so, the whole matter of column3: 3)	" Well
column4: I was raised to have a faith and a belief and have been a member of a church since I was a small boy. In our particular church
column5: we did not use that term
column6: ""born again
column7: '' so I don't know whether I would fit that -- that particular term. But I have -- thanks to my mother
column8: God rest her soul -- the firmest possible belief and faith in God. And I don't believe -- I believe
column9: I should say
column10: as Lincoln once said
column11: that I could not -- I would be the most stupid man in the world if I thought I could confront the duties of the office I hold if I could not turn to someone who was stronger and greater than all others. And I do resort to prayer. At the same time
column12: however
column13: I have not believed that prayer should be introduced into an election or be a part of a political campaign -- or religion a part of that campaign. As a matter of fact
column14: I think religion became a part of this campaign when Mr. Mondale's running mate said I wasn't a good Christian.  So
column15: it does play a part in my life. I have no hesitancy in saying so. And
column16: as I say
column17: I don't believe that I could carry on unless I had a belief in a higher authority and a belief that prayers are answered.

column1: The answer to your question is very simple about why I don't go to church. I have gone to church regularly all my life
column2: and I started to here in Washington. And now
column3: in the position I hold and in the world in which we live
column4: where Embassies do get blown up in Beirut -- we're supposed to talk about that on the debate the 21st
column5: I understand -- but I pose a threat to several hundred people if I go to church. I know the threats that are made against me. We all know the possibility of terrorism. We have seen the barricades that have had to be built around the White House. And
column6: therefore
column7: I don't feel -- and my minister knows this and supports me in this position -- I don't feel that I have a right to go to church
column8: knowing that my being there could cause something of the kind that we have seen in other places
column9: in Beirut
column10: for example. And I miss going to church
column11: but I think the Lord understands. [Applause]

column2: I accept President Reagan's affirmation of faith. I'm sure that we all accept and admire his commitment to his faith
column3: and we are strengthened
column4: all of us
column5: by that fact. I am a son of a Methodist minister. My wife is the daughter of a Presbyterian minister. And I don't know if I've been born again
column6: but I know I was born into a Christian family. And I believe I have sung at more weddings and more funerals than anybody ever to seek the Presidency. Whether that helps or not
column7: I don't know.  I have a deep religious faith. Our family does. It is fundamental. It's probably the reason that I'm in politics. I think our faith tells us
column8: instructs us
column9: about the moral life that we should lead. And I think we're all together on that.  What bothers me is this growing tendency to try to use one's own personal interpretation of faith politically
column10: to question others' faith
column11: and to try to use the instrumentalities of government to impose those views on others. All history tells us that that's a mistake.  When the Republican platform says that from here on out
column12: we're going to have a religious test for judges before they're selected for the Federal court
column13: and then Jerry Falwell announces that that means they get at least two Justices of the Supreme Court
column14: I think that's an abuse of faith in our country.  This nation is the most religious nation on Earth -- more people go to church and synagogues than any other nation on Earth -- and it's because we kept the politicians and the state out of the personal exercise of our faith. That's why faith in the United States is pure and unpolluted by the intervention of politicians. And I think if we want to continue -- as I do -- to have a religious nation
column15: lets keep that line and never cross it.

column1: No. What I object to -- [applause] -- what I object to -- what I object to is someone seeking to use his faith to question the faith of another or to use that faith and seek to use the power of government to impose it on others. A minister who is in civil rights or in the conservative movement
column2: because he believes his faith instructs him to do that
column3: I admire. The fact that the faith speaks to us and that we are moral people
column4: hopefully
column5: I accept and rejoice in. It's when you try to use that to undermine the integrity of private political -- or private religious faith and the use of the state is where -- for the most personal decisions in American life -- that's where I draw the line.

column3: because I find myself in so much agreement with Mr. Mondale. I
column4: too
column5: want that wall that is in the Constitution of separation of church and state to remain there. The only attacks I have made are on people who apparently would break away at that wall from the government side
column6: using the government
column7: using the power of the courts and so forth to hinder that part of the Constitution that says the government shall not only not establish a religion
column8: it shall not inhibit the practice of religion. And they have been using these things to have government
column9: through court orders
column10: inhibit the practice of religion. A child wants to say grace in a school cafeteria and a court rules that they can't do it because it's school property. These are they types of things that I think have been happening in a kind of a secular way that have been eroding that separation
column11: and I am opposed to that. With regard to a platform on the Supreme Court
column12: I can only say one thing about that. I have appointed one member to the Supreme Court: Sandra Day O'Connor. I'll stand on my record on that. And if I have the opportunity to appoint any more
column13: I'll do it in the same manner that I did in selecting her.

column1: The platform to which the President refers
column3: calls for a religious test in the selection of judges. And Jerry Falwell says that means we get two or three judges. And it would involve a religious test for the first time in American life. Let's take the example that the President cites. I believe in prayer. My family prays. We've never had any difficulty finding time to pray. But do we want a constitutional amendment adopted of the kind proposed by the President that gets the local politicians into the business of selecting prayers that our children must either recite in school or be embarrassed and asked to excuse themselves? Who would write the prayer? What would it say? How would it be resolved when those disputes occur?  It seems to me that a moment's reflection tells you why the United States Senate turned that amendment down
column4: because it will undermine the practice of honest faith in our country by politicizing it. We don't want that.

column3: 3)	" Well
column4: I was raised to have a faith and a belief and have been a member of a church since I was a small boy. In our particular church
column5: we did not use that term
column6: ""born again
column7: '' so I don't know whether I would fit that -- that particular term. But I have -- thanks to my mother
column8: God rest her soul -- the firmest possible belief and faith in God. And I don't believe -- I believe
column9: I should say
column10: as Lincoln once said
column11: that I could not -- I would be the most stupid man in the world if I thought I could confront the duties of the office I hold if I could not turn to someone who was stronger and greater than all others. And I do resort to prayer. At the same time
column12: however
column13: I have not believed that prayer should be introduced into an election or be a part of a political campaign -- or religion a part of that campaign. As a matter of fact
column14: I think religion became a part of this campaign when Mr. Mondale's running mate said I wasn't a good Christian.  So
column15: it does play a part in my life. I have no hesitancy in saying so. And
column16: as I say
column17: I don't believe that I could carry on unless I had a belief in a higher authority and a belief that prayers are answered.

column1: The answer to your question is very simple about why I don't go to church. I have gone to church regularly all my life
column2: and I started to here in Washington. And now
column3: in the position I hold and in the world in which we live
column4: where Embassies do get blown up in Beirut -- we're supposed to talk about that on the debate the 21st
column5: I understand -- but I pose a threat to several hundred people if I go to church. I know the threats that are made against me. We all know the possibility of terrorism. We have seen the barricades that have had to be built around the White House. And
column6: therefore
column7: I don't feel -- and my minister knows this and supports me in this position -- I don't feel that I have a right to go to church
column8: knowing that my being there could cause something of the kind that we have seen in other places
column9: in Beirut
column10: for example. And I miss going to church
column11: but I think the Lord understands. [Applause]

column2: I accept President Reagan's affirmation of faith. I'm sure that we all accept and admire his commitment to his faith
column3: and we are strengthened
column4: all of us
column5: by that fact. I am a son of a Methodist minister. My wife is the daughter of a Presbyterian minister. And I don't know if I've been born again
column6: but I know I was born into a Christian family. And I believe I have sung at more weddings and more funerals than anybody ever to seek the Presidency. Whether that helps or not
column7: I don't know.  I have a deep religious faith. Our family does. It is fundamental. It's probably the reason that I'm in politics. I think our faith tells us
column8: instructs us
column9: about the moral life that we should lead. And I think we're all together on that.  What bothers me is this growing tendency to try to use one's own personal interpretation of faith politically
column10: to question others' faith
column11: and to try to use the instrumentalities of government to impose those views on others. All history tells us that that's a mistake.  When the Republican platform says that from here on out
column12: we're going to have a religious test for judges before they're selected for the Federal court
column13: and then Jerry Falwell announces that that means they get at least two Justices of the Supreme Court
column14: I think that's an abuse of faith in our country.  This nation is the most religious nation on Earth -- more people go to church and synagogues than any other nation on Earth -- and it's because we kept the politicians and the state out of the personal exercise of our faith. That's why faith in the United States is pure and unpolluted by the intervention of politicians. And I think if we want to continue -- as I do -- to have a religious nation
column15: lets keep that line and never cross it.

column1: No. What I object to -- [applause] -- what I object to -- what I object to is someone seeking to use his faith to question the faith of another or to use that faith and seek to use the power of government to impose it on others. A minister who is in civil rights or in the conservative movement
column2: because he believes his faith instructs him to do that
column3: I admire. The fact that the faith speaks to us and that we are moral people
column4: hopefully
column5: I accept and rejoice in. It's when you try to use that to undermine the integrity of private political -- or private religious faith and the use of the state is where -- for the most personal decisions in American life -- that's where I draw the line.

column3: because I find myself in so much agreement with Mr. Mondale. I
column4: too
column5: want that wall that is in the Constitution of separation of church and state to remain there. The only attacks I have made are on people who apparently would break away at that wall from the government side
column6: using the government
column7: using the power of the courts and so forth to hinder that part of the Constitution that says the government shall not only not establish a religion
column8: it shall not inhibit the practice of religion. And they have been using these things to have government
column9: through court orders
column10: inhibit the practice of religion. A child wants to say grace in a school cafeteria and a court rules that they can't do it because it's school property. These are they types of things that I think have been happening in a kind of a secular way that have been eroding that separation
column11: and I am opposed to that. With regard to a platform on the Supreme Court
column12: I can only say one thing about that. I have appointed one member to the Supreme Court: Sandra Day O'Connor. I'll stand on my record on that. And if I have the opportunity to appoint any more
column13: I'll do it in the same manner that I did in selecting her.

column1: The platform to which the President refers
column3: calls for a religious test in the selection of judges. And Jerry Falwell says that means we get two or three judges. And it would involve a religious test for the first time in American life. Let's take the example that the President cites. I believe in prayer. My family prays. We've never had any difficulty finding time to pray. But do we want a constitutional amendment adopted of the kind proposed by the President that gets the local politicians into the business of selecting prayers that our children must either recite in school or be embarrassed and asked to excuse themselves? Who would write the prayer? What would it say? How would it be resolved when those disputes occur?  It seems to me that a moment's reflection tells you why the United States Senate turned that amendment down
column4: because it will undermine the practice of honest faith in our country by politicizing it. We don't want that.
