column3: 4)	" My answer is that this campaign isn't over yet. And when people vote
column4: I think you're going to see a very strong verdict by the American people that they favor the approach that I'm talking about. The American people want arms control. They don't want this arms race. And they don't want this deadly new effort to bring weapons into the heavens. And they want an American foreign policy that leads toward a safer world.  The American people see this debt
column5: and they know it's got to come down. And if it won't come down
column6: the economy's going to slow down
column7: maybe go into a recession. They see this tremendous influx and swamping of cheap foreign imports in this country that has cost over 3 million jobs
column8: given farmers the worst year in American history. And they know this debt must come down as well
column9: because it's unfair to our children.  The American people want this environment protected. They know that these toxic waste dumps should have been cleaned up a long time ago
column10: and they know that people's lives and health are being risked
column11: because we've had an administration that has been totally insensitive to the law and the demand for the protection of the environment.  The American people want their children educated. They want to get our edge back in science
column12: and they want a policy headed by the President that helps close this gap that's widening between the United States and Europe and Japan.  The American people want to keep opening doors. They want those civil rights laws enforced. They want the equal rights amendment ratified. They want equal pay for comparable effort for women. And they want it because they've understood from the beginning that when we open doors
column13: we're all stronger
column14: just as we were at the Olympics.  I think as you make the case
column15: the American people will increasingly come to our cause.

column2: tonight we had the first debate over the deficit. The President says it'll disappear automatically. I've said it's going to take some work. I think the American people will draw their own conclusions. Secondly
column3: I've said that I will not support the cuts in Social Security and Medicare and the rest that the President has proposed. The President answers that it didn't happen or
column4: if it did
column5: it was resolved later in a commission. As the record develops
column6: I think it's going to become increasingly clear that what I am saying and where I want to take this country is exactly where the country wants to go
column7: and the comparison of approaches is such that I think will lead to further strength.

column3: I'm running on the record. I think sometimes Mr. Mondale's running away from his. But I'm running on the record of what we have asked for. We'll continue to try to get things that we didn't get in a program that has already brought the rate of spending of government down from 17 percent to 6.1 percent
column4: a program of returning authority and autonomy to the local and State governments that has been unjustly seized by the Federal Government. And you might find those words in a Democratic platform of some years ago -- I know
column5: because I was a Democrat at that time. And I left the party eventually
column6: because I could no longer follow the turn in the Democratic leadership that took us down an entirely different path
column7: a path of centralizing authority in the Federal Government
column8: lacking trust in the American people. I promised
column9: when we took office
column10: that we would reduce inflation. We have
column11: to one-third of what it was. I promised that we would reduce taxes. We did
column12: 25 percent across the board. That barely held even with -- if it did that much -- with the gigantic tax increase imposed in 1977. But at least it took that burden away from them.  I said that we would create jobs for our people
column13: and we did -- 6 million in the last 20 or 21 months. I said that we would become respected in the world once again and that we would refurbish our national defense to the place that we could deal on the world scene and then seek disarmament
column14: reduction of arms
column15: and
column16: hopefully
column17: an elimination of nuclear weapons. We have done that.  All of the things that I said we would do
column18: from inflation being down
column19: interest rates being down
column20: unemployment falling
column21: all of those things we have done. And I think this is something the American people see.  I think they also know that we had a commission that came in a year ago with a recommendation on education -- on excellence in education. And today
column22: without the Federal Government being involved other than passing on to them
column23: the school districts
column24: the words from that commission
column25: we find 35 States with task forces now dealing with their educational problems. We find that schools are extending the curriculum to now have forced teaching of mathematics and science and so forth. All of these things have brought an improvement in the college entrance exams for the first time in some 20 years.  So
column26: I think that many Democrats are seeing the same thing this Democrat saw: The leadership isn't taking us where we want to go.

column1: There are tasks that government legitimately should enforce and tasks that government performs well
column2: and you've named some of them. Crime has come down the last 2 years
column3: for the first time in many
column4: many decades that it has come down -- or since we've kept records -- 2 consecutive years
column5: and last year it came down the biggest drop in crime that we've had. I think that we've had something to do with that
column6: just as we have with the drug problem nationwide. The environment? Yes
column7: I feel as strongly as anyone about the preservation of the environment. When we took office
column8: we found that the national parks were so dirty and contained so many hazards
column9: lack of safety features
column10: that we stopped buying additional park land until we had rectified this with what was to be a 5-year program -- but it's just about finished already -- a billion dollars. And now we're going back to budgeting for additional lands for our parks. We have added millions of acres to the wilderness lands
column11: to the game refuges. I think that we're out in front of most -- and I see that the red light is blinking
column12: so I can't continue. But I've got more.

column1: The President says that when the Democratic Party made its turn
column2: he left it. The year that he decided we had lost our way was the year that John F. Kennedy was running against Richard Nixon. I was chairman of ""Minnesotans for Kennedy;'' President Reagan was chairman of a thing called ""Democrats for Nixon.'' Now
column3: maybe we made a wrong turn with Kennedy
column4: but I'll be proud of supporting him all of my life. And I'm very happy that John Kennedy was elected
column5: because John Kennedy looked at the future with courage
column6: saw what needed to be done
column7: and understood his own government. The President just said that his government is shrinking. It's not. It's now the largest peacetime government ever in terms of the take from the total economy. And instead of retreating -- instead of being strong where we should be strong
column8: he wants to make it strong and intervene in the most private and personal questions in American life. That's where government should not be.

column1: Before I campaigned as a Democrat for a Republican candidate for President
column2: I had already voted for Dwight Eisenhower to be President of the United States. And so
column3: my change had come earlier than that. I hadn't gotten around to reregistering as yet. I found that was rather difficult to do. But I finally did it. There are some other things that have been said here -- back
column4: and you said that I might be able to dredge them up. Mr. Mondale referred to the farmers' worst year. The farmers are not the victims of anything this administration has done. The farmers were the victims of the double-digit inflation and the 21\1/2\-percent interest rates of the Carter-Mondale administration and the grain embargo
column5: which destroyed our reliability nationwide as a supplier. All of these things are presently being rectified
column6: and I think that we are going to salvage the farmers. As a matter of fact
column7: there has been less than one-quarter of 1 percent of foreclosures of the 270
column8: 000 loans from government that the farmers have.

I think that we've had something to do with that, just as we have with the drug problem nationwide. column3: 4)	" My answer is that this campaign isn't over yet. And when people vote
column4: I think you're going to see a very strong verdict by the American people that they favor the approach that I'm talking about. The American people want arms control. They don't want this arms race. And they don't want this deadly new effort to bring weapons into the heavens. And they want an American foreign policy that leads toward a safer world.  The American people see this debt
column5: and they know it's got to come down. And if it won't come down
column6: the economy's going to slow down
column7: maybe go into a recession. They see this tremendous influx and swamping of cheap foreign imports in this country that has cost over 3 million jobs
column8: given farmers the worst year in American history. And they know this debt must come down as well
column9: because it's unfair to our children.  The American people want this environment protected. They know that these toxic waste dumps should have been cleaned up a long time ago
column10: and they know that people's lives and health are being risked
column11: because we've had an administration that has been totally insensitive to the law and the demand for the protection of the environment.  The American people want their children educated. They want to get our edge back in science
column12: and they want a policy headed by the President that helps close this gap that's widening between the United States and Europe and Japan.  The American people want to keep opening doors. They want those civil rights laws enforced. They want the equal rights amendment ratified. They want equal pay for comparable effort for women. And they want it because they've understood from the beginning that when we open doors
column13: we're all stronger
column14: just as we were at the Olympics.  I think as you make the case
column15: the American people will increasingly come to our cause.

column2: tonight we had the first debate over the deficit. The President says it'll disappear automatically. I've said it's going to take some work. I think the American people will draw their own conclusions. Secondly
column3: I've said that I will not support the cuts in Social Security and Medicare and the rest that the President has proposed. The President answers that it didn't happen or
column4: if it did
column5: it was resolved later in a commission. As the record develops
column6: I think it's going to become increasingly clear that what I am saying and where I want to take this country is exactly where the country wants to go
column7: and the comparison of approaches is such that I think will lead to further strength.

column3: I'm running on the record. I think sometimes Mr. Mondale's running away from his. But I'm running on the record of what we have asked for. We'll continue to try to get things that we didn't get in a program that has already brought the rate of spending of government down from 17 percent to 6.1 percent
column4: a program of returning authority and autonomy to the local and State governments that has been unjustly seized by the Federal Government. And you might find those words in a Democratic platform of some years ago -- I know
column5: because I was a Democrat at that time. And I left the party eventually
column6: because I could no longer follow the turn in the Democratic leadership that took us down an entirely different path
column7: a path of centralizing authority in the Federal Government
column8: lacking trust in the American people. I promised
column9: when we took office
column10: that we would reduce inflation. We have
column11: to one-third of what it was. I promised that we would reduce taxes. We did
column12: 25 percent across the board. That barely held even with -- if it did that much -- with the gigantic tax increase imposed in 1977. But at least it took that burden away from them.  I said that we would create jobs for our people
column13: and we did -- 6 million in the last 20 or 21 months. I said that we would become respected in the world once again and that we would refurbish our national defense to the place that we could deal on the world scene and then seek disarmament
column14: reduction of arms
column15: and
column16: hopefully
column17: an elimination of nuclear weapons. We have done that.  All of the things that I said we would do
column18: from inflation being down
column19: interest rates being down
column20: unemployment falling
column21: all of those things we have done. And I think this is something the American people see.  I think they also know that we had a commission that came in a year ago with a recommendation on education -- on excellence in education. And today
column22: without the Federal Government being involved other than passing on to them
column23: the school districts
column24: the words from that commission
column25: we find 35 States with task forces now dealing with their educational problems. We find that schools are extending the curriculum to now have forced teaching of mathematics and science and so forth. All of these things have brought an improvement in the college entrance exams for the first time in some 20 years.  So
column26: I think that many Democrats are seeing the same thing this Democrat saw: The leadership isn't taking us where we want to go.

column1: There are tasks that government legitimately should enforce and tasks that government performs well
column2: and you've named some of them. Crime has come down the last 2 years
column3: for the first time in many
column4: many decades that it has come down -- or since we've kept records -- 2 consecutive years
column5: and last year it came down the biggest drop in crime that we've had. I think that we've had something to do with that
column6: just as we have with the drug problem nationwide. The environment? Yes
column7: I feel as strongly as anyone about the preservation of the environment. When we took office
column8: we found that the national parks were so dirty and contained so many hazards
column9: lack of safety features
column10: that we stopped buying additional park land until we had rectified this with what was to be a 5-year program -- but it's just about finished already -- a billion dollars. And now we're going back to budgeting for additional lands for our parks. We have added millions of acres to the wilderness lands
column11: to the game refuges. I think that we're out in front of most -- and I see that the red light is blinking
column12: so I can't continue. But I've got more.

column1: The President says that when the Democratic Party made its turn
column2: he left it. The year that he decided we had lost our way was the year that John F. Kennedy was running against Richard Nixon. I was chairman of ""Minnesotans for Kennedy;'' President Reagan was chairman of a thing called ""Democrats for Nixon.'' Now
column3: maybe we made a wrong turn with Kennedy
column4: but I'll be proud of supporting him all of my life. And I'm very happy that John Kennedy was elected
column5: because John Kennedy looked at the future with courage
column6: saw what needed to be done
column7: and understood his own government. The President just said that his government is shrinking. It's not. It's now the largest peacetime government ever in terms of the take from the total economy. And instead of retreating -- instead of being strong where we should be strong
column8: he wants to make it strong and intervene in the most private and personal questions in American life. That's where government should not be.

column1: Before I campaigned as a Democrat for a Republican candidate for President
column2: I had already voted for Dwight Eisenhower to be President of the United States. And so
column3: my change had come earlier than that. I hadn't gotten around to reregistering as yet. I found that was rather difficult to do. But I finally did it. There are some other things that have been said here -- back
column4: and you said that I might be able to dredge them up. Mr. Mondale referred to the farmers' worst year. The farmers are not the victims of anything this administration has done. The farmers were the victims of the double-digit inflation and the 21\1/2\-percent interest rates of the Carter-Mondale administration and the grain embargo
column5: which destroyed our reliability nationwide as a supplier. All of these things are presently being rectified
column6: and I think that we are going to salvage the farmers. As a matter of fact
column7: there has been less than one-quarter of 1 percent of foreclosures of the 270
column8: 000 loans from government that the farmers have.

column1: Crime has come down the last 2 years, for the first time in many, many decades that it has come down -- or since we've kept records -- 2 consecutive years, and last year it came down the biggest drop in crime that we've had. I think that we've had something to do with that, just as we have with the drug problem nationwide. column3: 4)	" My answer is that this campaign isn't over yet. And when people vote
column4: I think you're going to see a very strong verdict by the American people that they favor the approach that I'm talking about. The American people want arms control. They don't want this arms race. And they don't want this deadly new effort to bring weapons into the heavens. And they want an American foreign policy that leads toward a safer world.  The American people see this debt
column5: and they know it's got to come down. And if it won't come down
column6: the economy's going to slow down
column7: maybe go into a recession. They see this tremendous influx and swamping of cheap foreign imports in this country that has cost over 3 million jobs
column8: given farmers the worst year in American history. And they know this debt must come down as well
column9: because it's unfair to our children.  The American people want this environment protected. They know that these toxic waste dumps should have been cleaned up a long time ago
column10: and they know that people's lives and health are being risked
column11: because we've had an administration that has been totally insensitive to the law and the demand for the protection of the environment.  The American people want their children educated. They want to get our edge back in science
column12: and they want a policy headed by the President that helps close this gap that's widening between the United States and Europe and Japan.  The American people want to keep opening doors. They want those civil rights laws enforced. They want the equal rights amendment ratified. They want equal pay for comparable effort for women. And they want it because they've understood from the beginning that when we open doors
column13: we're all stronger
column14: just as we were at the Olympics.  I think as you make the case
column15: the American people will increasingly come to our cause.

column2: tonight we had the first debate over the deficit. The President says it'll disappear automatically. I've said it's going to take some work. I think the American people will draw their own conclusions. Secondly
column3: I've said that I will not support the cuts in Social Security and Medicare and the rest that the President has proposed. The President answers that it didn't happen or
column4: if it did
column5: it was resolved later in a commission. As the record develops
column6: I think it's going to become increasingly clear that what I am saying and where I want to take this country is exactly where the country wants to go
column7: and the comparison of approaches is such that I think will lead to further strength.

And now we're going back to budgeting for additional lands for our parks. We have added millions of acres to the wilderness lands
column11: to the game refuges. I think that we're out in front of most -- and I see that the red light is blinking
column12: so I can't continue. But I've got more.

column1: The President says that when the Democratic Party made its turn
column2: he left it. The year that he decided we had lost our way was the year that John F. Kennedy was running against Richard Nixon. I was chairman of ""Minnesotans for Kennedy;'' President Reagan was chairman of a thing called ""Democrats for Nixon.'' Now
column3: maybe we made a wrong turn with Kennedy
column4: but I'll be proud of supporting him all of my life. And I'm very happy that John Kennedy was elected
column5: because John Kennedy looked at the future with courage
column6: saw what needed to be done
column7: and understood his own government. The President just said that his government is shrinking. It's not. It's now the largest peacetime government ever in terms of the take from the total economy. And instead of retreating -- instead of being strong where we should be strong
column8: he wants to make it strong and intervene in the most private and personal questions in American life. That's where government should not be.

column1: Before I campaigned as a Democrat for a Republican candidate for President
column2: I had already voted for Dwight Eisenhower to be President of the United States. And so
column3: my change had come earlier than that. I hadn't gotten around to reregistering as yet. I found that was rather difficult to do. But I finally did it. There are some other things that have been said here -- back
column4: and you said that I might be able to dredge them up. Mr. Mondale referred to the farmers' worst year. The farmers are not the victims of anything this administration has done. The farmers were the victims of the double-digit inflation and the 21\1/2\-percent interest rates of the Carter-Mondale administration and the grain embargo
column5: which destroyed our reliability nationwide as a supplier. All of these things are presently being rectified
column6: and I think that we are going to salvage the farmers. As a matter of fact
column7: there has been less than one-quarter of 1 percent of foreclosures of the 270
column8: 000 loans from government that the farmers have.

column3: 4)	" My answer is that this campaign isn't over yet. And when people vote
column4: I think you're going to see a very strong verdict by the American people that they favor the approach that I'm talking about. The American people want arms control. They don't want this arms race. And they don't want this deadly new effort to bring weapons into the heavens. And they want an American foreign policy that leads toward a safer world.  The American people see this debt
column5: and they know it's got to come down. And if it won't come down
column6: the economy's going to slow down
column7: maybe go into a recession. They see this tremendous influx and swamping of cheap foreign imports in this country that has cost over 3 million jobs
column8: given farmers the worst year in American history. And they know this debt must come down as well
column9: because it's unfair to our children.  The American people want this environment protected. They know that these toxic waste dumps should have been cleaned up a long time ago
column10: and they know that people's lives and health are being risked
column11: because we've had an administration that has been totally insensitive to the law and the demand for the protection of the environment.  The American people want their children educated. They want to get our edge back in science
column12: and they want a policy headed by the President that helps close this gap that's widening between the United States and Europe and Japan.  The American people want to keep opening doors. They want those civil rights laws enforced. They want the equal rights amendment ratified. They want equal pay for comparable effort for women. And they want it because they've understood from the beginning that when we open doors
column13: we're all stronger
column14: just as we were at the Olympics.  I think as you make the case
column15: the American people will increasingly come to our cause.

column2: tonight we had the first debate over the deficit. The President says it'll disappear automatically. I've said it's going to take some work. I think the American people will draw their own conclusions. Secondly
column3: I've said that I will not support the cuts in Social Security and Medicare and the rest that the President has proposed. The President answers that it didn't happen or
column4: if it did
column5: it was resolved later in a commission. As the record develops
column6: I think it's going to become increasingly clear that what I am saying and where I want to take this country is exactly where the country wants to go
column7: and the comparison of approaches is such that I think will lead to further strength.

column3: I'm running on the record. I think sometimes Mr. Mondale's running away from his. But I'm running on the record of what we have asked for. We'll continue to try to get things that we didn't get in a program that has already brought the rate of spending of government down from 17 percent to 6.1 percent
column4: a program of returning authority and autonomy to the local and State governments that has been unjustly seized by the Federal Government. And you might find those words in a Democratic platform of some years ago -- I know
column5: because I was a Democrat at that time. And I left the party eventually
column6: because I could no longer follow the turn in the Democratic leadership that took us down an entirely different path
column7: a path of centralizing authority in the Federal Government
column8: lacking trust in the American people. I promised
column9: when we took office
column10: that we would reduce inflation. We have
column11: to one-third of what it was. I promised that we would reduce taxes. We did
column12: 25 percent across the board. That barely held even with -- if it did that much -- with the gigantic tax increase imposed in 1977. But at least it took that burden away from them.  I said that we would create jobs for our people
column13: and we did -- 6 million in the last 20 or 21 months. I said that we would become respected in the world once again and that we would refurbish our national defense to the place that we could deal on the world scene and then seek disarmament
column14: reduction of arms
column15: and
column16: hopefully
column17: an elimination of nuclear weapons. We have done that.  All of the things that I said we would do
column18: from inflation being down
column19: interest rates being down
column20: unemployment falling
column21: all of those things we have done. And I think this is something the American people see.  I think they also know that we had a commission that came in a year ago with a recommendation on education -- on excellence in education. And today
column22: without the Federal Government being involved other than passing on to them
column23: the school districts
column24: the words from that commission
column25: we find 35 States with task forces now dealing with their educational problems. We find that schools are extending the curriculum to now have forced teaching of mathematics and science and so forth. All of these things have brought an improvement in the college entrance exams for the first time in some 20 years.  So
column26: I think that many Democrats are seeing the same thing this Democrat saw: The leadership isn't taking us where we want to go.

column1: There are tasks that government legitimately should enforce and tasks that government performs well
column2: and you've named some of them. Crime has come down the last 2 years
column3: for the first time in many
column4: many decades that it has come down -- or since we've kept records -- 2 consecutive years
column5: and last year it came down the biggest drop in crime that we've had. I think that we've had something to do with that
column6: just as we have with the drug problem nationwide. The environment? Yes
column7: I feel as strongly as anyone about the preservation of the environment. When we took office
column8: we found that the national parks were so dirty and contained so many hazards
column9: lack of safety features
column10: that we stopped buying additional park land until we had rectified this with what was to be a 5-year program -- but it's just about finished already -- a billion dollars. And now we're going back to budgeting for additional lands for our parks. We have added millions of acres to the wilderness lands
column11: to the game refuges. I think that we're out in front of most -- and I see that the red light is blinking
column12: so I can't continue. But I've got more.

column1: The President says that when the Democratic Party made its turn
column2: he left it. The year that he decided we had lost our way was the year that John F. Kennedy was running against Richard Nixon. I was chairman of ""Minnesotans for Kennedy;'' President Reagan was chairman of a thing called ""Democrats for Nixon.'' Now
column3: maybe we made a wrong turn with Kennedy
column4: but I'll be proud of supporting him all of my life. And I'm very happy that John Kennedy was elected
column5: because John Kennedy looked at the future with courage
column6: saw what needed to be done
column7: and understood his own government. The President just said that his government is shrinking. It's not. It's now the largest peacetime government ever in terms of the take from the total economy. And instead of retreating -- instead of being strong where we should be strong
column8: he wants to make it strong and intervene in the most private and personal questions in American life. That's where government should not be.

column3: 5)	" I have believed that in the appointment of judges that all that was specified in the party platform was that they respect the sanctity of human life. Now
column4: that I would want to see in any judge and with regard to any issue having to do with human life. But with regard to abortion
column5: and I have a feeling that this is -- there's been some reference without naming it here in the remarks of Mr. Mondale tied to injecting religion into government. With me
column6: abortion is not a problem of religion
column7: it's a problem of the Constitution. I believe that until and unless someone can establish that the unborn child is not a living human being
column8: then that child is already protected by the Constitution
column9: which guarantees life
column10: liberty
column11: and the pursuit of happiness to all of us. And I think that this is what we should concentrate on
column12: is trying -- I know there were weeks and weeks of testimony before a Senate committee
column13: there were medical authorities
column14: there were religious -- there were clerics there -- everyone talking about this matter of prolife. And at the end of all of that
column15: not one shred of evidence was introduced that the unborn child was not alive. We have seen premature births that are now grown-up
column16: happy people going around.  Also
column17: there is a strange dichotomy in this whole position about our courts ruling that abortion is not the taking of a human life. In California
column18: sometime ago
column19: a man beat a woman so savagely that her unborn child was born dead with a fractured skull
column20: and the California State Legislature unanimously passed a law that was signed by the then-Democratic Governor -- signed a law that said that any man who so abuses a pregnant woman that he causes the death of her unborn child shall be charged with murder. Now
column21: isn't it strange that that same woman could have taken the life of her unborn child
column22: and it was abortion and not murder
column23: but if somebody else does it
column24: that's murder? And it used the term ""death of the unborn child.''  So
column25: this has been my feeling about abortion
column26: that we have a problem now to determine -- and all the evidence so far comes down on the side of the unborn child being a living human being.

column1: The laws regarding that always were State laws. It was only when the Supreme Court handed down a decision that the Federal Government intervened in what had always been a State policy. Our laws against murder are State laws. So
column2: I would think that this would be the point of enforcement on this. As I say
column3: I feel that we have a problem here to resolve. And no one has approached it from that matter. It does not happen that the church that I belong to had that as part of its dogma. I know that some churches do.  Now
column4: it is a sin if you're taking a human life. At the same time
column5: in our Judeo-Christian tradition
column6: we recognize the right of taking a human life in self-defense. And therefore
column7: I've always believed that a mother
column8: if medically it is determined that her life is at risk if she goes through with the pregnancy
column9: she has a right then to take the life of even her own unborn child in defense of her own.

column1: This is one of the most emotional and difficult issues that could possibly be debated. I think your questions
column3: underscore the fact there is probably no way that government should or could answer this question in every individual case and in the private lives of the American people. The constitutional amendment proposed by President Reagan would make it a crime for a woman to have an abortion if she had been raped or suffered from incest. Is it really the view of the American people
column4: however you feel on the question of abortion
column5: that government ought to be reaching into your livingrooms and making choices like this? I think it cannot work
column6: won't work
column7: and will lead to all kinds of cynical evasions of the law. Those who can afford to have them will continue to have them. The disadvantaged will go out in the back alley as they used to do.  I think these questions are inherently personal and moral
column8: and every individual instance is different. Every American should be aware of the seriousness of the step. But there are some things that government can do and some things they cannot do.  Now
column9: the example that the President cites has nothing to do with abortion. Somebody went to a woman and nearly killed her. That's always been a serious crime and always should be a serious crime. But how does that compare with the problem of a woman who is raped? Do we really want those decisions made by judges who've been picked because they will agree to find the person guilty? I don't think so
column10: and I think it's going in exactly the wrong direction.  In America
column11: on basic moral questions we have always let the people decide in their own personal lives. We haven't felt so insecure that we've reached for the club of state to have our point of view. It's been a good instinct. And we're the most religious people on Earth.  One final point: President Reagan
column12: as Governor of California
column13: signed a bill which is perhaps the most liberal proabortion bill of any State in the Union.

column1: The basic decision of the Supreme Court is that each person has to make this judgment in her own life
column2: and that's the way it's been done. And it's a personal and private
column3: moral judgment. I don't know the answer to when life begins. And it's not that simple
column4: either. You've got another life involved. And if it's rape
column5: how do you draw moral judgments on that? If it's incest
column6: how do you draw moral judgments on that? Does every woman in America have to present herself before some judge picked by Jerry Falwell to clear her personal judgment? It won't work. [Applause]

column2: with regard to this being a personal choice
column3: isn't that what a murderer is insisting on
column4: his or her right to kill someone because of whatever fault they think justifies that? Now
column5: I'm not capable
column6: and I don't think you are
column7: any of us
column8: to make this determination that must be made with regard to human life. I am simply saying that I believe that that's where the effort should be directed -- to make that determination.  I don't think that any of us should be called upon here to stand and make a decision as to what other things might come under the self-defense tradition. That
column9: too
column10: would have to be worked out then
column11: when you once recognize that we're talking about a life. But in this great society of ours
column12: wouldn't it make a lot more sense
column13: in this gentle and kind society
column14: if we had a program that made it possible for when incidents come along in which someone feels they must do away with that unborn child
column15: that instead we make it available for the adoption? There are a million and a half people out there standing in line waiting to adopt children who can't have them any other way.

column2: and that's why I was a principal sponsor of a liberal adoption law
column3: so that more of these children could come to term
column4: so that the young mothers were educated
column5: so we found an option
column6: an alternative. I'm all for that. But the question is whether this other option proposed by the President should be pursued. And I don't agree with it. Since I've got about 20 seconds
column7: let me just say one thing. The question of agriculture came up a minute ago. Net farm income is off 50 percent in the last 3 years
column8: and every farmer knows it. And the effect of these economic policies is like a massive grain embargo
column9: which has caused farm exports to drop 20 percent. It's been a big failure. I opposed the grain embargo in my administration. I'm opposed to these policies as well.

column3: 5)	" I have believed that in the appointment of judges that all that was specified in the party platform was that they respect the sanctity of human life. Now
column4: that I would want to see in any judge and with regard to any issue having to do with human life. But with regard to abortion
column5: and I have a feeling that this is -- there's been some reference without naming it here in the remarks of Mr. Mondale tied to injecting religion into government. With me
column6: abortion is not a problem of religion
column7: it's a problem of the Constitution. I believe that until and unless someone can establish that the unborn child is not a living human being
column8: then that child is already protected by the Constitution
column9: which guarantees life
column10: liberty
column11: and the pursuit of happiness to all of us. And I think that this is what we should concentrate on
column12: is trying -- I know there were weeks and weeks of testimony before a Senate committee
column13: there were medical authorities

column15: not one shred of evidence was introduced that the unborn child was not alive. We have seen premature births that are now grown-up
column16: happy people going around.  Also
column17: there is a strange dichotomy in this whole position about our courts ruling that abortion is not the taking of a human life. In California
column18: sometime ago
column19: a man beat a woman so savagely that her unborn child was born dead with a fractured skull
column20: and the California State Legislature unanimously passed a law that was signed by the then-Democratic Governor -- signed a law that said that any man who so abuses a pregnant woman that he causes the death of her unborn child shall be charged with murder. Now
column21: isn't it strange that that same woman could have taken the life of her unborn child
column22: and it was abortion and not murder
column23: but if somebody else does it
column24: that's murder? And it used the term ""death of the unborn child.''  So
column25: this has been my feeling about abortion

column1: The laws regarding that always were State laws. It was only when the Supreme Court handed down a decision that the Federal Government intervened in what had always been a State policy. Our laws against murder are State laws. So
column2: I would think that this would be the point of enforcement on this. As I say
column3: I feel that we have a problem here to resolve. And no one has approached it from that matter. It does not happen that the church that I belong to had that as part of its dogma. I know that some churches do.  Now
column4: it is a sin if you're taking a human life. At the same time
column5: in our Judeo-Christian tradition
column6: we recognize the right of taking a human life in self-defense. And therefore
column7: I've always believed that a mother
column8: if medically it is determined that her life is at risk if she goes through with the pregnancy
column9: she has a right then to take the life of even her own unborn child in defense of her own.

column1: This is one of the most emotional and difficult issues that could possibly be debated. I think your questions
column3: underscore the fact there is probably no way that government should or could answer this question in every individual case and in the private lives of the American people. The constitutional amendment proposed by President Reagan would make it a crime for a woman to have an abortion if she had been raped or suffered from incest. Is it really the view of the American people
column4: however you feel on the question of abortion
column5: that government ought to be reaching into your livingrooms and making choices like this? I think it cannot work
column6: won't work
column7: and will lead to all kinds of cynical evasions of the law. Those who can afford to have them will continue to have them. The disadvantaged will go out in the back alley as they used to do.  I think these questions are inherently personal and moral
column8: and every individual instance is different. Every American should be aware of the seriousness of the step. But there are some things that government can do and some things they cannot do.  Now
column9: the example that the President cites has nothing to do with abortion. Somebody went to a woman and nearly killed her. That's always been a serious crime and always should be a serious crime. But how does that compare with the problem of a woman who is raped? Do we really want those decisions made by judges who've been picked because they will agree to find the person guilty? I don't think so
column10: and I think it's going in exactly the wrong direction.  In America
column11: on basic moral questions we have always let the people decide in their own personal lives. We haven't felt so insecure that we've reached for the club of state to have our point of view. It's been a good instinct. And we're the most religious people on Earth.  One final point: President Reagan
column12: as Governor of California
column13: signed a bill which is perhaps the most liberal proabortion bill of any State in the Union.

column1: The basic decision of the Supreme Court is that each person has to make this judgment in her own life
column2: and that's the way it's been done. And it's a personal and private
column3: moral judgment. I don't know the answer to when life begins. And it's not that simple
column4: either. You've got another life involved. And if it's rape
column5: how do you draw moral judgments on that? If it's incest
column6: how do you draw moral judgments on that? Does every woman in America have to present herself before some judge picked by Jerry Falwell to clear her personal judgment? It won't work. [Applause]

column2: with regard to this being a personal choice
column3: isn't that what a murderer is insisting on
column4: his or her right to kill someone because of whatever fault they think justifies that? Now
column5: I'm not capable
column6: and I don't think you are
column7: any of us
column8: to make this determination that must be made with regard to human life. I am simply saying that I believe that that's where the effort should be directed -- to make that determination.  I don't think that any of us should be called upon here to stand and make a decision as to what other things might come under the self-defense tradition. That
column9: too
column10: would have to be worked out then
column11: when you once recognize that we're talking about a life. But in this great society of ours
column12: wouldn't it make a lot more sense
column13: in this gentle and kind society
column14: if we had a program that made it possible for when incidents come along in which someone feels they must do away with that unborn child
column15: that instead we make it available for the adoption? There are a million and a half people out there standing in line waiting to adopt children who can't have them any other way.

column2: and that's why I was a principal sponsor of a liberal adoption law
column3: so that more of these children could come to term
column4: so that the young mothers were educated
column5: so we found an option
column6: an alternative. I'm all for that. But the question is whether this other option proposed by the President should be pursued. And I don't agree with it. Since I've got about 20 seconds
column7: let me just say one thing. The question of agriculture came up a minute ago. Net farm income is off 50 percent in the last 3 years
column8: and every farmer knows it. And the effect of these economic policies is like a massive grain embargo
column9: which has caused farm exports to drop 20 percent. It's been a big failure. I opposed the grain embargo in my administration. I'm opposed to these policies as well.

column3: 5)	" I have believed that in the appointment of judges that all that was specified in the party platform was that they respect the sanctity of human life. Now
column4: that I would want to see in any judge and with regard to any issue having to do with human life. But with regard to abortion
column5: and I have a feeling that this is -- there's been some reference without naming it here in the remarks of Mr. Mondale tied to injecting religion into government. With me
column6: abortion is not a problem of religion
column7: it's a problem of the Constitution. I believe that until and unless someone can establish that the unborn child is not a living human being
column8: then that child is already protected by the Constitution
column9: which guarantees life
column10: liberty
column11: and the pursuit of happiness to all of us. And I think that this is what we should concentrate on
column12: is trying -- I know there were weeks and weeks of testimony before a Senate committee
column13: there were medical authorities
column14: there were religious -- there were clerics there -- everyone talking about this matter of prolife. And at the end of all of that
column15: not one shred of evidence was introduced that the unborn child was not alive. We have seen premature births that are now grown-up
column16: happy people going around.  Also
column17: there is a strange dichotomy in this whole position about our courts ruling that abortion is not the taking of a human life. In California
column18: sometime ago
column19: a man beat a woman so savagely that her unborn child was born dead with a fractured skull
column20: and the California State Legislature unanimously passed a law that was signed by the then-Democratic Governor -- signed a law that said that any man who so abuses a pregnant woman that he causes the death of her unborn child shall be charged with murder. Now
column21: isn't it strange that that same woman could have taken the life of her unborn child
column22: and it was abortion and not murder
column23: but if somebody else does it
column24: that's murder? And it used the term ""death of the unborn child.''  So
column25: this has been my feeling about abortion
column26: that we have a problem now to determine -- and all the evidence so far comes down on the side of the unborn child being a living human being.

column1: The laws regarding that always were State laws. It was only when the Supreme Court handed down a decision that the Federal Government intervened in what had always been a State policy. Our laws against murder are State laws. So
column2: I would think that this would be the point of enforcement on this. As I say
column3: I feel that we have a problem here to resolve. And no one has approached it from that matter. It does not happen that the church that I belong to had that as part of its dogma. I know that some churches do.  Now
column4: it is a sin if you're taking a human life. At the same time
column5: in our Judeo-Christian tradition
column6: we recognize the right of taking a human life in self-defense. And therefore
column7: I've always believed that a mother
column8: if medically it is determined that her life is at risk if she goes through with the pregnancy
column9: she has a right then to take the life of even her own unborn child in defense of her own.

column1: This is one of the most emotional and difficult issues that could possibly be debated. I think your questions
column3: underscore the fact there is probably no way that government should or could answer this question in every individual case and in the private lives of the American people. The constitutional amendment proposed by President Reagan would make it a crime for a woman to have an abortion if she had been raped or suffered from incest. Is it really the view of the American people
column4: however you feel on the question of abortion
column5: that government ought to be reaching into your livingrooms and making choices like this? I think it cannot work
column6: won't work
column7: and will lead to all kinds of cynical evasions of the law. Those who can afford to have them will continue to have them. The disadvantaged will go out in the back alley as they used to do.  I think these questions are inherently personal and moral
column8: and every individual instance is different. Every American should be aware of the seriousness of the step. But there are some things that government can do and some things they cannot do.  Now
column9: the example that the President cites has nothing to do with abortion. Somebody went to a woman and nearly killed her. That's always been a serious crime and always should be a serious crime. But how does that compare with the problem of a woman who is raped? Do we really want those decisions made by judges who've been picked because they will agree to find the person guilty? I don't think so
column10: and I think it's going in exactly the wrong direction.  In America
column11: on basic moral questions we have always let the people decide in their own personal lives. We haven't felt so insecure that we've reached for the club of state to have our point of view. It's been a good instinct. And we're the most religious people on Earth.  One final point: President Reagan
column12: as Governor of California
column13: signed a bill which is perhaps the most liberal proabortion bill of any State in the Union.

column1: The basic decision of the Supreme Court is that each person has to make this judgment in her own life
column2: and that's the way it's been done. And it's a personal and private
column3: moral judgment. I don't know the answer to when life begins. And it's not that simple
column4: either. You've got another life involved. And if it's rape
column5: how do you draw moral judgments on that? If it's incest
column6: how do you draw moral judgments on that? Does every woman in America have to present herself before some judge picked by Jerry Falwell to clear her personal judgment? It won't work. [Applause]

column2: with regard to this being a personal choice
column3: isn't that what a murderer is insisting on
column4: his or her right to kill someone because of whatever fault they think justifies that? Now
column5: I'm not capable

column7: any of us

I don't think that any of us should be called upon here to stand and make a decision as to what other things might come under the self-defense tradition. That

column11: when you once recognize that we're talking about a life. But in this great society of ours
column12: wouldn't it make a lot more sense
column13: in this gentle and kind society

column2: and that's why I was a principal sponsor of a liberal adoption law
column3: so that more of these children could come to term
column4: so that the young mothers were educated
column5: so we found an option
column6: an alternative. I'm all for that. But the question is whether this other option proposed by the President should be pursued. And I don't agree with it. Since I've got about 20 seconds
column7: let me just say one thing. The question of agriculture came up a minute ago. Net farm income is off 50 percent in the last 3 years
column8: and every farmer knows it. And the effect of these economic policies is like a massive grain embargo
column9: which has caused farm exports to drop 20 percent. It's been a big failure. I opposed the grain embargo in my administration. I'm opposed to these policies as well.

column3: 5)	" I have believed that in the appointment of judges that all that was specified in the party platform was that they respect the sanctity of human life. Now
column4: that I would want to see in any judge and with regard to any issue having to do with human life. But with regard to abortion
column5: and I have a feeling that this is -- there's been some reference without naming it here in the remarks of Mr. Mondale tied to injecting religion into government. With me
column6: abortion is not a problem of religion
column7: it's a problem of the Constitution. I believe that until and unless someone can establish that the unborn child is not a living human being
column8: then that child is already protected by the Constitution
column9: which guarantees life
column10: liberty
column11: and the pursuit of happiness to all of us. And I think that this is what we should concentrate on
column12: is trying -- I know there were weeks and weeks of testimony before a Senate committee
column13: there were medical authorities
column14: there were religious -- there were clerics there -- everyone talking about this matter of prolife. And at the end of all of that
column15: not one shred of evidence was introduced that the unborn child was not alive. We have seen premature births that are now grown-up
column16: happy people going around.  Also
column17: there is a strange dichotomy in this whole position about our courts ruling that abortion is not the taking of a human life. In California
column18: sometime ago
column19: a man beat a woman so savagely that her unborn child was born dead with a fractured skull
column20: and the California State Legislature unanimously passed a law that was signed by the then-Democratic Governor -- signed a law that said that any man who so abuses a pregnant woman that he causes the death of her unborn child shall be charged with murder. Now
column21: isn't it strange that that same woman could have taken the life of her unborn child
column22: and it was abortion and not murder
column23: but if somebody else does it
column24: that's murder? And it used the term ""death of the unborn child.''  So
column25: this has been my feeling about abortion
column26: that we have a problem now to determine -- and all the evidence so far comes down on the side of the unborn child being a living human being.

column1: The laws regarding that always were State laws. It was only when the Supreme Court handed down a decision that the Federal Government intervened in what had always been a State policy. Our laws against murder are State laws. So
column2: I would think that this would be the point of enforcement on this. As I say
column3: I feel that we have a problem here to resolve. And no one has approached it from that matter. It does not happen that the church that I belong to had that as part of its dogma. I know that some churches do.  Now
column4: it is a sin if you're taking a human life. At the same time
column5: in our Judeo-Christian tradition
column6: we recognize the right of taking a human life in self-defense. And therefore
column7: I've always believed that a mother
column8: if medically it is determined that her life is at risk if she goes through with the pregnancy
column9: she has a right then to take the life of even her own unborn child in defense of her own.

column1: This is one of the most emotional and difficult issues that could possibly be debated. I think your questions
column3: underscore the fact there is probably no way that government should or could answer this question in every individual case and in the private lives of the American people. The constitutional amendment proposed by President Reagan would make it a crime for a woman to have an abortion if she had been raped or suffered from incest. Is it really the view of the American people
column4: however you feel on the question of abortion
column5: that government ought to be reaching into your livingrooms and making choices like this? I think it cannot work
column6: won't work
column7: and will lead to all kinds of cynical evasions of the law. Those who can afford to have them will continue to have them. The disadvantaged will go out in the back alley as they used to do.  I think these questions are inherently personal and moral
column8: and every individual instance is different. Every American should be aware of the seriousness of the step. But there are some things that government can do and some things they cannot do.  Now
column9: the example that the President cites has nothing to do with abortion. Somebody went to a woman and nearly killed her. That's always been a serious crime and always should be a serious crime. But how does that compare with the problem of a woman who is raped? Do we really want those decisions made by judges who've been picked because they will agree to find the person guilty? I don't think so
column10: and I think it's going in exactly the wrong direction.  In America
column11: on basic moral questions we have always let the people decide in their own personal lives. We haven't felt so insecure that we've reached for the club of state to have our point of view. It's been a good instinct. And we're the most religious people on Earth.  One final point: President Reagan
column12: as Governor of California
column13: signed a bill which is perhaps the most liberal proabortion bill of any State in the Union.

column1: The basic decision of the Supreme Court is that each person has to make this judgment in her own life
column2: and that's the way it's been done. And it's a personal and private
column3: moral judgment. I don't know the answer to when life begins. And it's not that simple
column4: either. You've got another life involved. And if it's rape
column5: how do you draw moral judgments on that? If it's incest
column6: how do you draw moral judgments on that? Does every woman in America have to present herself before some judge picked by Jerry Falwell to clear her personal judgment? It won't work. [Applause]

column2: with regard to this being a personal choice
column3: isn't that what a murderer is insisting on
column4: his or her right to kill someone because of whatever fault they think justifies that? Now
column5: I'm not capable
column6: and I don't think you are
column7: any of us
column8: to make this determination that must be made with regard to human life. I am simply saying that I believe that that's where the effort should be directed -- to make that determination.  I don't think that any of us should be called upon here to stand and make a decision as to what other things might come under the self-defense tradition. That
column9: too
column10: would have to be worked out then
column11: when you once recognize that we're talking about a life. But in this great society of ours
column12: wouldn't it make a lot more sense
column13: in this gentle and kind society
column14: if we had a program that made it possible for when incidents come along in which someone feels they must do away with that unborn child
column15: that instead we make it available for the adoption? There are a million and a half people out there standing in line waiting to adopt children who can't have them any other way.

column2: and that's why I was a principal sponsor of a liberal adoption law
column3: so that more of these children could come to term
column4: so that the young mothers were educated
column5: so we found an option
column6: an alternative. I'm all for that. But the question is whether this other option proposed by the President should be pursued. And I don't agree with it. Since I've got about 20 seconds
column7: let me just say one thing. The question of agriculture came up a minute ago. Net farm income is off 50 percent in the last 3 years
column8: and every farmer knows it. And the effect of these economic policies is like a massive grain embargo
column9: which has caused farm exports to drop 20 percent. It's been a big failure. I opposed the grain embargo in my administration. I'm opposed to these policies as well.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: some of those facts and figures just don't stand up. Yes
column5: there has been an increase in poverty
column6: but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here. It has begun to decline
column7: but it is still going up. On the other hand
column8: women heads of household -- single women heads of household have -- for the first time there's been a turndown in the rate of poverty for them. We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty
column9: it all had to do with their private earnings. It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.  We are spending now 37 percent more on food for the hungry in all the various types of programs than was spent in 1980. We're spending a third more on all of the -- well
column10: all of the programs of human service. We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2
column12: 000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850
column13: 000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them. We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits. We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.  Some time ago
column14: Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind. Half -- one out of two of the full-time college students in the United States are receiving some form of Federal aid. But there
column15: again
column16: we found people that there under the previous administration
column17: families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans. We didn't think that was right. And so
column18: we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college
column19: their family incomes were so low.  So
column20: there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been
column21: taking care of more people than they ever have. 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over
column22: leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.

column1: That had nothing to do with the other thing of talking about their needs or anything. I remember distinctly
column2: I was segueing into another subject. I was talking about the things that have been accomplished
column3: and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism
column4: the new spirit that we're finding all over America. And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people. So
column5: that was the only place that that was used. I did avoid
column6: I'm afraid
column7: in my previous answer
column8: also
column9: the idea of uneven
column10: yes. There is no way that the recovery is even across the country
column11: just as in the depths of the recession
column12: there were some parts of the country that were worse off
column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges
column6: and it's attributable to the deficit. Everybody -- every economist
column7: every businessman -- believes that. Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that. Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee
column8: Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that. That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy. It's causing high interest rates. It's ruining us in trade. It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years. The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: some of those facts and figures just don't stand up. Yes
column5: there has been an increase in poverty
column6: but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here. It has begun to decline
column7: but it is still going up. On the other hand
column8: women heads of household -- single women heads of household have -- for the first time there's been a turndown in the rate of poverty for them. We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty
column9: it all had to do with their private earnings. It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.  We are spending now 37 percent more on food for the hungry in all the various types of programs than was spent in 1980. We're spending a third more on all of the -- well
column10: all of the programs of human service. We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2
column12: 000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850
column13: 000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them. We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits. We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.  Some time ago
column14: Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind. Half -- one out of two of the full-time college students in the United States are receiving some form of Federal aid. But there
column15: again
column16: we found people that there under the previous administration
column17: families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans. We didn't think that was right. And so
column18: we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college
column19: their family incomes were so low.  So
column20: there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been
column21: taking care of more people than they ever have. 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over
column22: leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.

column1: That had nothing to do with the other thing of talking about their needs or anything. I remember distinctly
column2: I was segueing into another subject. I was talking about the things that have been accomplished
column3: and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism
column4: the new spirit that we're finding all over America. And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people. So
column5: that was the only place that that was used. I did avoid
column6: I'm afraid
column7: in my previous answer
column8: also
column9: the idea of uneven
column10: yes. There is no way that the recovery is even across the country
column11: just as in the depths of the recession
column12: there were some parts of the country that were worse off
column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges
column6: and it's attributable to the deficit. Everybody -- every economist
column7: every businessman -- believes that. Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that. Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee
column8: Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that. That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy. It's causing high interest rates. It's ruining us in trade. It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years. The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --
