column3: 7)	" Well
column4: some of those facts and figures just don't stand up. Yes
column5: there has been an increase in poverty
column6: but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here. It has begun to decline
column7: but it is still going up. On the other hand
column8: women heads of household -- single women heads of household have -- for the first time there's been a turndown in the rate of poverty for them. We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty
column9: it all had to do with their private earnings. It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.  We are spending now 37 percent more on food for the hungry in all the various types of programs than was spent in 1980. We're spending a third more on all of the -- well
column10: all of the programs of human service. We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2
column12: 000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850
column13: 000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them. We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits. We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.  Some time ago
column14: Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind. Half -- one out of two of the full-time college students in the United States are receiving some form of Federal aid. But there
column15: again
column16: we found people that there under the previous administration
column17: families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans. We didn't think that was right. And so
column18: we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college
column19: their family incomes were so low.  So
column20: there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been
column21: taking care of more people than they ever have. 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over
column22: leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.

column1: That had nothing to do with the other thing of talking about their needs or anything. I remember distinctly
column2: I was segueing into another subject. I was talking about the things that have been accomplished
column3: and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism
column4: the new spirit that we're finding all over America. And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people. So
column5: that was the only place that that was used. I did avoid
column6: I'm afraid
column7: in my previous answer
column8: also
column9: the idea of uneven
column10: yes. There is no way that the recovery is even across the country
column11: just as in the depths of the recession
column12: there were some parts of the country that were worse off
column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges
column6: and it's attributable to the deficit. Everybody -- every economist
column7: every businessman -- believes that. Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that. Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee
column8: Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that. That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy. It's causing high interest rates. It's ruining us in trade. It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years. The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --

column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges
column6: and it's attributable to the deficit. Everybody -- every economist
column7: every businessman -- believes that. Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that. Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee
column8: Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that. That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy. It's causing high interest rates. It's ruining us in trade. It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years. The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: some of those facts and figures just don't stand up. Yes
column5: there has been an increase in poverty
column6: but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here. It has begun to decline
column7: but it is still going up. On the other hand
column8: women heads of household -- single women heads of household have -- for the first time there's been a turndown in the rate of poverty for them. We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty
column9: it all had to do with their private earnings. It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.  We are spending now 37 percent more on food for the hungry in all the various types of programs than was spent in 1980. We're spending a third more on all of the -- well
column10: all of the programs of human service. We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2
column12: 000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850
column13: 000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them. We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits. We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.  Some time ago
column14: Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind. Half -- one out of two of the full-time college students in the United States are receiving some form of Federal aid. But there
column15: again
column16: we found people that there under the previous administration
column17: families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans. We didn't think that was right. And so
column18: we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college
column19: their family incomes were so low.  So
column20: there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been
column21: taking care of more people than they ever have. 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over
column22: leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.

column1: That had nothing to do with the other thing of talking about their needs or anything. I remember distinctly
column2: I was segueing into another subject. I was talking about the things that have been accomplished
column3: and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism
column4: the new spirit that we're finding all over America. And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people. So
column5: that was the only place that that was used. I did avoid
column6: I'm afraid
column7: in my previous answer
column8: also
column9: the idea of uneven
column10: yes. There is no way that the recovery is even across the country
column11: just as in the depths of the recession
column12: there were some parts of the country that were worse off
column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: some of those facts and figures just don't stand up. Yes
column5: there has been an increase in poverty
column6: but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here. It has begun to decline
column7: but it is still going up. On the other hand
column8: women heads of household -- single women heads of household have -- for the first time there's been a turndown in the rate of poverty for them. We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty
column9: it all had to do with their private earnings. It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.  We are spending now 37 percent more on food for the hungry in all the various types of programs than was spent in 1980. We're spending a third more on all of the -- well
column10: all of the programs of human service. We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2
column12: 000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850
column13: 000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them. We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits. We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.  Some time ago
column14: Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind. Half -- one out of two of the full-time college students in the United States are receiving some form of Federal aid. But there
column15: again
column16: we found people that there under the previous administration
column17: families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans. We didn't think that was right. And so
column18: we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college
column19: their family incomes were so low.  So
column20: there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been
column21: taking care of more people than they ever have. 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over
column22: leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.

column1: That had nothing to do with the other thing of talking about their needs or anything. I remember distinctly
column2: I was segueing into another subject. I was talking about the things that have been accomplished
column3: and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism
column4: the new spirit that we're finding all over America. And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people. So
column5: that was the only place that that was used. I did avoid
column6: I'm afraid
column7: in my previous answer
column8: also
column9: the idea of uneven
column10: yes. There is no way that the recovery is even across the country
column11: just as in the depths of the recession
column12: there were some parts of the country that were worse off
column13: but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.  We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one
column14: until the recovery is complete across the country.

column2: we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed. Number two
column3: we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program. I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them
column4: but not as a substitute for the others. Certainly education and training is crucial. If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees
column5: they're not going to get jobs.  The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found. The other thing is
column6: we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.  There is no question that the poor are worse off. I think the President genuinely believes that they're better off. But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago. How you can cut school lunches
column7: how you can cut student assistance
column8: how you can cut housing
column9: how you can cut disability benefits
column10: how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example
column11: the disabled
column12: who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better
column13: I don't know. Now
column14: we need a tight budget
column15: but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life
column16: and they're hurting.  One final point if I might. There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today
column17: and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports. We are now $120 billion of imports
column18: 3 million jobs lost
column19: and farmers are having their worst year. That's another reason to get the deficit down.

column1: I think the American people want to make certain that that dollar is wisely spent. I think they stand for civil rights. I know they're all for education in science and training
column2: which I strongly support. They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest. I think the business community wants to get involved. I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved. I think that's part of it. I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else. I'm opposed to that
column3: too.

column1: Yes. The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them. There is a connection between interest rates and inflation
column2: but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 21\1/2\
column3: down toward the 12 or 13 figure. And while they were coming down
column4: the deficits had started their great increase. They were going up. Now
column5: if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down. The interest rates are based on inflation. And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low. I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting
column6: not hoping
column7: that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again. Well
column8: it isn't going to go back up. We're going to see that it doesn't.  And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.

column3: you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates. I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980
column4: and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on. There's no way of glossing around that. But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981
column5: what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today. And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges
column6: and it's attributable to the deficit. Everybody -- every economist
column7: every businessman -- believes that. Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that. Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee
column8: Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that. That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy. It's causing high interest rates. It's ruining us in trade. It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years. The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --

column3: 8)	" Do you want to give me some suggestions? [Laughter] I'm going to use my time a little differently. I'm going to give the President some credit. I think the President has done some things to raise the sense of spirit
column4: morale
column5: good feeling in this country
column6: and he's entitled to credit for that. What I think we need
column7: however
column8: is not just that but to move forward
column9: not just congratulating ourselves but challenging ourselves to get on with the business of dealing with America's problems. I think in education
column10: when he lectured the country about the importance of discipline
column11: I didn't like it at first
column12: but I think it helped a little bit. But now we need both that kind of discipline and the resources and the consistent leadership that allows this country to catch up in education and science and training.  I like President Reagan. And this is not personal -- there are deep differences about our future
column13: and that's the basis of my campaign.

column2: I have stood up and told the American people that that $263 billion deficit must come down. And I've done what no candidate for President has ever done
column3: I told you before the election what I'd do. Mr. Reagan
column4: as you saw tonight -- President Reagan takes the position it will disappear by magic. It was once called voodoo economics. I wish the President would say: Yes
column5: the CBO is right. Yes
column6: we have a $263 billion deficit. This is how I'm going to get it done. Don't talk about growth
column7: because even though we need growth
column8: that's not helping. It's going to go in the other direction
column9: as they've estimated.  And give us a plan. What will you cut? Whose taxes will you raise? Will you finally touch that defense budget? Are you going to go after Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and the handicapped again as you did last time? If you'd just tell us what you're going to do
column10: then the American people could compare my plan for the future with your plan. And that's the way it should be. The American people would be in charge.

column3: I have to start with a smile
column4: since his kind words to me. I'll tell you what I think has been the most outrageous thing in political dialog
column5: both in this campaign and the one in '82. And that is the continued discussion and claim that somehow I am the villain who is going to pull the Social Security checks out from those people who are dependent on them.  And why I think it is outrageous -- first of all
column6: it isn't true. But why it is outrageous is because
column7: for political advantage
column8: every time they do that
column9: they scare millions of senior citizens who are totally dependent on Social Security
column10: have no place else to turn. And they have to live and go to bed at night thinking
column11: ""Is this true? Is someone going to take our check away from us and leave us destitute?'' And I don't think that that should be a part of political dialog.  Now
column12: to -- I still -- I just have a minute here?

column3: let's lay it to rest once and for all. I told you never would I do such a thing. But I tell you also now
column4: Social Security has nothing to do with the deficit. Social Security is totally funded by the payroll tax levied on employer and employee. If you reduce the out-go of Social Security
column5: that money would not go into the general fund to reduce a deficit. It would go into the Social Security Trust Fund. So
column6: Social Security has nothing to do with balancing a budget or erasing or lowering the deficit.  Now
column7: again
column8: to get to whether I am depending on magic
column9: I think I have talked in straight economic terms about a program of recovery that I was told wouldn't work. And then
column10: after it worked
column11: I was told that lowering taxes would increase inflation. And none of these things happened. It is working
column12: and we're going to continue on that same line.  As to what we might do
column13: and find in further savings cuts
column14: no
column15: we're not going to starve the hungry. But we have 2
column16: 478 specific recommendations from a commission of more than 2
column17: 000 business people in this country
column18: through the Grace commission
column19: that we're studying right now -- and we've already implemented 17 percent of them -- that are recommendations as to how to make government more efficient
column20: more economic.

column1: Why the deficits are so much of a problem for him now
column3: when the deficit was $52 billion and everyone was panicking about that
column4: he said
column5: no
column6: that he thought it ought to be bigger
column7: because a bigger deficit would stimulate the economy and would help do away with unemployment. In 1979 he made similar statements
column8: the same effect
column9: that the deficits -- there was nothing wrong with having deficits. Remember
column10: there was a trillion dollars in debt before we got here. That's got to be paid by our children and grandchildren
column11: too
column12: if we don't do it. And I'm hoping we can start some payments on it before we get through here. That's why I want another 4 years.

column2: we've just finished almost the whole debate. And the American people don't have the slightest clue about what President Reagan will do about these deficits. [Laughter] And yet
column3: that's the most important single issue of our time. I did support the '76 measure that he told about
column4: because we were in a deep recession and we needed some stimulation. But I will say as a Democrat
column5: I was a real piker
column6: Mr. President. In 1979 we ran a $29 billion deficit all year. This administration seems to run that every morning. And the result is exactly what we see. This economy is starting to run downhill. Housing is off. Last report on new purchases
column7: it's the lowest since 1982. Growth is a little over 3 percent now. Many people are predicting a recession. And the flow of imports into this country is swamping the American people.  We've got to deal with this problem
column8: and those of us who want to be your President should tell you now what we're going to do
column9: so you can make a judgment.

column2: I might as well just go with -- --

column1: I don't think so. I'm all confused now.

column3: 8)	" Do you want to give me some suggestions? [Laughter] I'm going to use my time a little differently. I'm going to give the President some credit. I think the President has done some things to raise the sense of spirit
column4: morale
column5: good feeling in this country
column6: and he's entitled to credit for that. What I think we need
column7: however
column8: is not just that but to move forward
column9: not just congratulating ourselves but challenging ourselves to get on with the business of dealing with America's problems. I think in education
column10: when he lectured the country about the importance of discipline
column11: I didn't like it at first
column12: but I think it helped a little bit. But now we need both that kind of discipline and the resources and the consistent leadership that allows this country to catch up in education and science and training.  I like President Reagan. And this is not personal -- there are deep differences about our future
column13: and that's the basis of my campaign.

column2: I have stood up and told the American people that that $263 billion deficit must come down. And I've done what no candidate for President has ever done
column3: I told you before the election what I'd do. Mr. Reagan
column4: as you saw tonight -- President Reagan takes the position it will disappear by magic. It was once called voodoo economics. I wish the President would say: Yes
column5: the CBO is right. Yes
column6: we have a $263 billion deficit. This is how I'm going to get it done. Don't talk about growth
column7: because even though we need growth
column8: that's not helping. It's going to go in the other direction
column9: as they've estimated.  And give us a plan. What will you cut? Whose taxes will you raise? Will you finally touch that defense budget? Are you going to go after Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and the handicapped again as you did last time? If you'd just tell us what you're going to do
column10: then the American people could compare my plan for the future with your plan. And that's the way it should be. The American people would be in charge.

column3: I have to start with a smile
column4: since his kind words to me. I'll tell you what I think has been the most outrageous thing in political dialog
column5: both in this campaign and the one in '82. And that is the continued discussion and claim that somehow I am the villain who is going to pull the Social Security checks out from those people who are dependent on them.  And why I think it is outrageous -- first of all
column6: it isn't true. But why it is outrageous is because
column7: for political advantage
column8: every time they do that
column9: they scare millions of senior citizens who are totally dependent on Social Security
column10: have no place else to turn. And they have to live and go to bed at night thinking
column11: ""Is this true? Is someone going to take our check away from us and leave us destitute?'' And I don't think that that should be a part of political dialog.  Now
column12: to -- I still -- I just have a minute here?

column3: let's lay it to rest once and for all. I told you never would I do such a thing. But I tell you also now
column4: Social Security has nothing to do with the deficit. Social Security is totally funded by the payroll tax levied on employer and employee. If you reduce the out-go of Social Security
column5: that money would not go into the general fund to reduce a deficit. It would go into the Social Security Trust Fund. So
column6: Social Security has nothing to do with balancing a budget or erasing or lowering the deficit.  Now
column7: again
column8: to get to whether I am depending on magic
column9: I think I have talked in straight economic terms about a program of recovery that I was told wouldn't work. And then
column10: after it worked
column11: I was told that lowering taxes would increase inflation. And none of these things happened. It is working
column12: and we're going to continue on that same line.  As to what we might do
column13: and find in further savings cuts
column14: no
column15: we're not going to starve the hungry. But we have 2
column16: 478 specific recommendations from a commission of more than 2
column17: 000 business people in this country
column18: through the Grace commission
column19: that we're studying right now -- and we've already implemented 17 percent of them -- that are recommendations as to how to make government more efficient
column20: more economic.

column1: Why the deficits are so much of a problem for him now
column3: when the deficit was $52 billion and everyone was panicking about that
column4: he said
column5: no
column6: that he thought it ought to be bigger
column7: because a bigger deficit would stimulate the economy and would help do away with unemployment. In 1979 he made similar statements
column8: the same effect
column9: that the deficits -- there was nothing wrong with having deficits. Remember
column10: there was a trillion dollars in debt before we got here. That's got to be paid by our children and grandchildren
column11: too
column12: if we don't do it. And I'm hoping we can start some payments on it before we get through here. That's why I want another 4 years.

column2: we've just finished almost the whole debate. And the American people don't have the slightest clue about what President Reagan will do about these deficits. [Laughter] And yet
column3: that's the most important single issue of our time. I did support the '76 measure that he told about
column4: because we were in a deep recession and we needed some stimulation. But I will say as a Democrat
column5: I was a real piker
column6: Mr. President. In 1979 we ran a $29 billion deficit all year. This administration seems to run that every morning. And the result is exactly what we see. This economy is starting to run downhill. Housing is off. Last report on new purchases
column7: it's the lowest since 1982. Growth is a little over 3 percent now. Many people are predicting a recession. And the flow of imports into this country is swamping the American people.  We've got to deal with this problem
column8: and those of us who want to be your President should tell you now what we're going to do
column9: so you can make a judgment.

column2: I might as well just go with -- --

column3: 8)	" Do you want to give me some suggestions? [Laughter] I'm going to use my time a little differently. I'm going to give the President some credit. I think the President has done some things to raise the sense of spirit
column4: morale
column5: good feeling in this country
column6: and he's entitled to credit for that. What I think we need
column7: however
column8: is not just that but to move forward
column9: not just congratulating ourselves but challenging ourselves to get on with the business of dealing with America's problems. I think in education
column10: when he lectured the country about the importance of discipline
column11: I didn't like it at first
column12: but I think it helped a little bit. But now we need both that kind of discipline and the resources and the consistent leadership that allows this country to catch up in education and science and training.  I like President Reagan. And this is not personal -- there are deep differences about our future
column13: and that's the basis of my campaign.

column2: I have stood up and told the American people that that $263 billion deficit must come down. And I've done what no candidate for President has ever done
column3: I told you before the election what I'd do. Mr. Reagan
column4: as you saw tonight -- President Reagan takes the position it will disappear by magic. It was once called voodoo economics. I wish the President would say: Yes
column5: the CBO is right. Yes
column6: we have a $263 billion deficit. This is how I'm going to get it done. Don't talk about growth
column7: because even though we need growth
column8: that's not helping. It's going to go in the other direction
column9: as they've estimated.  And give us a plan. What will you cut? Whose taxes will you raise? Will you finally touch that defense budget? Are you going to go after Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and the handicapped again as you did last time? If you'd just tell us what you're going to do
column10: then the American people could compare my plan for the future with your plan. And that's the way it should be. The American people would be in charge.

column3: I have to start with a smile
column4: since his kind words to me. I'll tell you what I think has been the most outrageous thing in political dialog
column5: both in this campaign and the one in '82. And that is the continued discussion and claim that somehow I am the villain who is going to pull the Social Security checks out from those people who are dependent on them.  And why I think it is outrageous -- first of all
column6: it isn't true. But why it is outrageous is because
column7: for political advantage
column8: every time they do that
column9: they scare millions of senior citizens who are totally dependent on Social Security
column10: have no place else to turn. And they have to live and go to bed at night thinking
column11: ""Is this true? Is someone going to take our check away from us and leave us destitute?'' And I don't think that that should be a part of political dialog.  Now
column12: to -- I still -- I just have a minute here?

column3: let's lay it to rest once and for all. I told you never would I do such a thing. But I tell you also now
column4: Social Security has nothing to do with the deficit. Social Security is totally funded by the payroll tax levied on employer and employee. If you reduce the out-go of Social Security
column5: that money would not go into the general fund to reduce a deficit. It would go into the Social Security Trust Fund. So
column6: Social Security has nothing to do with balancing a budget or erasing or lowering the deficit.  Now
column7: again
column8: to get to whether I am depending on magic
column9: I think I have talked in straight economic terms about a program of recovery that I was told wouldn't work. And then
column10: after it worked
column11: I was told that lowering taxes would increase inflation. And none of these things happened. It is working
column12: and we're going to continue on that same line.  As to what we might do
column13: and find in further savings cuts
column14: no
column15: we're not going to starve the hungry. But we have 2
column16: 478 specific recommendations from a commission of more than 2
column17: 000 business people in this country
column18: through the Grace commission
column19: that we're studying right now -- and we've already implemented 17 percent of them -- that are recommendations as to how to make government more efficient
column20: more economic.

column4: he said

column7: because a bigger deficit would stimulate the economy and would help do away with unemployment. In 1979 he made similar statements
column8: the same effect
column9: that the deficits -- there was nothing wrong with having deficits. Remember
column10: there was a trillion dollars in debt before we got here. That's got to be paid by our children and grandchildren
column11: too
column12: if we don't do it. And I'm hoping we can start some payments on it before we get through here. That's why I want another 4 years.

column2: we've just finished almost the whole debate. And the American people don't have the slightest clue about what President Reagan will do about these deficits. [Laughter] And yet
column3: that's the most important single issue of our time. I did support the '76 measure that he told about
column4: because we were in a deep recession and we needed some stimulation. But I will say as a Democrat
column5: I was a real piker
column6: Mr. President. In 1979 we ran a $29 billion deficit all year. This administration seems to run that every morning. And the result is exactly what we see. This economy is starting to run downhill. Housing is off. Last report on new purchases
column7: it's the lowest since 1982. Growth is a little over 3 percent now. Many people are predicting a recession. And the flow of imports into this country is swamping the American people.  We've got to deal with this problem
column8: and those of us who want to be your President should tell you now what we're going to do
column9: so you can make a judgment.

column3: 9)	" Well
column4: we'll include it in that.

column3: I asked you
column4: the American people
column5: a question. I asked: ""Are you better off than you were 4 years before?'' The answer to that obviously was no
column6: and as the result
column7: I was elected to this office and promised a new beginning. Now
column8: maybe I'm expected to ask that same question again. I'm not going to
column9: because I think that all of you -- or not everyone
column10: those people that are in those pockets of poverty and haven't caught up
column11: they couldn't answer the way I would want them to -- but I think that most of the people in this country would say
column12: yes
column13: they are better off than they were 4 years ago.  The question
column14: I think
column15: should be enlarged. Is America better off than it was 4 years ago? And I believe the answer to that has to also be ""yes.'' I promised a new beginning. So far
column16: it is only a beginning. If the job were finished
column17: I might have thought twice about seeking reelection for this job.  But we now have an economy that
column18: for the first time -- well
column19: let's put it this way: In the first half of 1980
column20: gross national product was down a minus 3.7 percent. The first half of '84 it's up 8\1/2\ percent. Productivity in the first half of 1980 was down a minus 2 percent. Today it is up a plus 4 percent.  Personal earnings after taxes per capita have gone up almost $3
column21: 000 in these 4 years. In 1980 -- or 1979
column22: a person with a fixed income of $8
column23: 000 was $500 above the poverty line
column24: and this maybe explains why there are the numbers still in poverty. By 1980 that same person was $500 below the poverty line.  We have restored much of our economy. With regard to business investment
column25: it is higher than it has been since 1949. So
column26: there seems to be no shortage of investment capital. We have
column27: as I said
column28: cut the taxes
column30: and for 2 years now it has stayed down there
column31: not at double digit
column32: but in the range of 4 or below. We believe that we had also promised that we would make our country more secure.  Yes
column33: we have an increase in the defense budget. But back then we had planes that couldn't fly for lack of spare parts or pilots. We had navy vessels that couldn't leave harbor because of lack of crew or
column34: again
column35: lack of spare parts. Today we're well on our way to a 600-ship navy. We have 543 at present.  We have -- our military
column36: the morale is high. I think the people should understand that two-thirds of the defense budget pays for pay and salary
column37: or pay and pension. And then you add to that food and wardrobe
column39: and you only have a small portion going for weapons. But I am determined that if ever our men are called on
column40: they should have the best that we can provide in the manner of tools and weapons. There has been reference to expensive spare parts
column42: we are the ones who found those.  I think we've given the American people back their spirit. I think there's an optimism in the land and a patriotism
column43: and I think that we're in a position once again to heed the words of Thomas Paine
column44: who said: ""We have it in our power to begin the world over again.''

column1: I want to thank the League of Women Voters and the city of Louisville for hosting this evening's debate. I want to thank President Reagan for agreeing to debate. He didn't have to
column3: and we all appreciate it. The President's favorite question is: Are you better off? Well
column4: if you're wealthy
column5: you're better off. If you're middle income
column6: you're about where you were. And if you're modest income
column7: you're worse off. That's what the economists tell us.  But is that really the question that should be asked? Isn't the real question is will we be better off? Will our children be better off? Are we building the future that this nation needs? I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future
column8: not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems
column9: you'll see that we need new leadership.  Are we better of with this arms race? Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens? Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights? Are we better off when we load our children with this fantastic debt? Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children? Can we say
column10: really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?  I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest. I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves. And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare
column11: as the record shows we did
column12: I think that was mean-spirited. When we terminated 400
column13: 000 desperate
column14: hopeless
column15: defenseless Americans who were on disability -- confused and unable to defend themselves
column16: and just laid them out on the street
column17: as we did for 4 years
column18: I don't think that's what America is all about.  America is a fair society
column19: and it is not right that Vice President Bush pays less in taxes than the janitor who helps him. I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.  I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment. And contrary to what the President says
column20: I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful. These laws are not being enforced
column21: have not been enforced
column22: and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price. That's not fair for our future.  I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education
column23: our learning
column24: and our science and training
column25: because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.  I believe in opening doors. We won the Olympics
column26: in part
column27: because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women. I have been for those efforts all my life. The President's record is quite different.  The question is our future. President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments
column28: ""We are great
column29: but we can be greater.'' We can be better if we face our future
column30: rejoice in our strengths
column31: face our problems
column32: and by solving them
column33: build a better society for our children.  Thank you.

column3: I asked you
column4: the American people
column5: a question. I asked: ""Are you better off than you were 4 years before?'' The answer to that obviously was no
column6: and as the result
column7: I was elected to this office and promised a new beginning. Now
column8: maybe I'm expected to ask that same question again. I'm not going to
column9: because I think that all of you -- or not everyone
column10: those people that are in those pockets of poverty and haven't caught up
column11: they couldn't answer the way I would want them to -- but I think that most of the people in this country would say
column12: yes
column13: they are better off than they were 4 years ago.  The question
column14: I think
column15: should be enlarged. Is America better off than it was 4 years ago? And I believe the answer to that has to also be ""yes.'' I promised a new beginning. So far
column16: it is only a beginning. If the job were finished
column17: I might have thought twice about seeking reelection for this job.  But we now have an economy that
column18: for the first time -- well
column19: let's put it this way: In the first half of 1980
column20: gross national product was down a minus 3.7 percent. The first half of '84 it's up 8\1/2\ percent. Productivity in the first half of 1980 was down a minus 2 percent. Today it is up a plus 4 percent.  Personal earnings after taxes per capita have gone up almost $3
column21: 000 in these 4 years. In 1980 -- or 1979
column22: a person with a fixed income of $8
column23: 000 was $500 above the poverty line
column24: and this maybe explains why there are the numbers still in poverty. By 1980 that same person was $500 below the poverty line.  We have restored much of our economy. With regard to business investment
column25: it is higher than it has been since 1949. So
column26: there seems to be no shortage of investment capital. We have
column27: as I said
column28: cut the taxes
column30: and for 2 years now it has stayed down there
column31: not at double digit
column32: but in the range of 4 or below. We believe that we had also promised that we would make our country more secure.  Yes
column33: we have an increase in the defense budget. But back then we had planes that couldn't fly for lack of spare parts or pilots. We had navy vessels that couldn't leave harbor because of lack of crew or
column34: again
column35: lack of spare parts. Today we're well on our way to a 600-ship navy. We have 543 at present.  We have -- our military
column36: the morale is high. I think the people should understand that two-thirds of the defense budget pays for pay and salary
column37: or pay and pension. And then you add to that food and wardrobe
column39: and you only have a small portion going for weapons. But I am determined that if ever our men are called on
column40: they should have the best that we can provide in the manner of tools and weapons. There has been reference to expensive spare parts
column42: we are the ones who found those.  I think we've given the American people back their spirit. I think there's an optimism in the land and a patriotism
column43: and I think that we're in a position once again to heed the words of Thomas Paine
column44: who said: ""We have it in our power to begin the world over again.''

column1: I want to thank the League of Women Voters and the city of Louisville for hosting this evening's debate. I want to thank President Reagan for agreeing to debate. He didn't have to
column3: and we all appreciate it. The President's favorite question is: Are you better off? Well
column4: if you're wealthy
column5: you're better off. If you're middle income
column6: you're about where you were. And if you're modest income
column7: you're worse off. That's what the economists tell us.  But is that really the question that should be asked? Isn't the real question is will we be better off? Will our children be better off? Are we building the future that this nation needs? I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future
column8: not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems
column9: you'll see that we need new leadership.  Are we better of with this arms race? Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens? Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights? Are we better off when we load our children with this fantastic debt? Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children? Can we say
column10: really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?  I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest. I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves. And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare
column11: as the record shows we did
column12: I think that was mean-spirited. When we terminated 400
column13: 000 desperate
column14: hopeless
column15: defenseless Americans who were on disability -- confused and unable to defend themselves
column16: and just laid them out on the street
column17: as we did for 4 years
column18: I don't think that's what America is all about.  America is a fair society
column19: and it is not right that Vice President Bush pays less in taxes than the janitor who helps him. I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.  I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment. And contrary to what the President says
column20: I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful. These laws are not being enforced
column21: have not been enforced
column22: and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price. That's not fair for our future.  I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education
column23: our learning
column24: and our science and training
column25: because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.  I believe in opening doors. We won the Olympics
column26: in part
column27: because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women. I have been for those efforts all my life. The President's record is quite different.  The question is our future. President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments
column28: ""We are great
column29: but we can be greater.'' We can be better if we face our future
column30: rejoice in our strengths
column31: face our problems
column32: and by solving them
column33: build a better society for our children.  Thank you.

column1: I want to thank the League of Women Voters and the city of Louisville for hosting this evening's debate. I want to thank President Reagan for agreeing to debate. He didn't have to
column3: and we all appreciate it. The President's favorite question is: Are you better off? Well
column4: if you're wealthy
column5: you're better off. If you're middle income
column6: you're about where you were. And if you're modest income
column7: you're worse off. That's what the economists tell us.  But is that really the question that should be asked? Isn't the real question is will we be better off? Will our children be better off? Are we building the future that this nation needs? I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future
column8: not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems
column9: you'll see that we need new leadership.  Are we better of with this arms race? Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens? Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights? Are we better off when we load our children with this fantastic debt? Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children? Can we say
column10: really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?  I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest. I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves. And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare
column11: as the record shows we did
column12: I think that was mean-spirited. When we terminated 400
column13: 000 desperate
column14: hopeless
column15: defenseless Americans who were on disability -- confused and unable to defend themselves
column16: and just laid them out on the street
column17: as we did for 4 years
column18: I don't think that's what America is all about.  America is a fair society
column19: and it is not right that Vice President Bush pays less in taxes than the janitor who helps him. I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.  I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment. And contrary to what the President says
column20: I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful. These laws are not being enforced
column21: have not been enforced
column22: and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price. That's not fair for our future.  I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education
column23: our learning
column24: and our science and training
column25: because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.  I believe in opening doors. We won the Olympics
column26: in part
column27: because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women. I have been for those efforts all my life. The President's record is quite different.  The question is our future. President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments
column28: ""We are great
column29: but we can be greater.'' We can be better if we face our future
column30: rejoice in our strengths
column31: face our problems
column32: and by solving them
column33: build a better society for our children.  Thank you.

column3: I asked you
column4: the American people
column5: a question. I asked: ""Are you better off than you were 4 years before?'' The answer to that obviously was no
column6: and as the result
column7: I was elected to this office and promised a new beginning. Now
column8: maybe I'm expected to ask that same question again. I'm not going to
column9: because I think that all of you -- or not everyone
column10: those people that are in those pockets of poverty and haven't caught up
column11: they couldn't answer the way I would want them to -- but I think that most of the people in this country would say
column12: yes
column13: they are better off than they were 4 years ago.  The question
column14: I think
column15: should be enlarged. Is America better off than it was 4 years ago? And I believe the answer to that has to also be ""yes.'' I promised a new beginning. So far
column16: it is only a beginning. If the job were finished
column17: I might have thought twice about seeking reelection for this job.  But we now have an economy that
column18: for the first time -- well
column19: let's put it this way: In the first half of 1980
column20: gross national product was down a minus 3.7 percent. The first half of '84 it's up 8\1/2\ percent. Productivity in the first half of 1980 was down a minus 2 percent. Today it is up a plus 4 percent.  Personal earnings after taxes per capita have gone up almost $3
column21: 000 in these 4 years. In 1980 -- or 1979
column22: a person with a fixed income of $8
column23: 000 was $500 above the poverty line
column24: and this maybe explains why there are the numbers still in poverty. By 1980 that same person was $500 below the poverty line.  We have restored much of our economy. With regard to business investment
column25: it is higher than it has been since 1949. So
column26: there seems to be no shortage of investment capital. We have
column27: as I said
column28: cut the taxes
column30: and for 2 years now it has stayed down there
column31: not at double digit
column32: but in the range of 4 or below. We believe that we had also promised that we would make our country more secure.  Yes
column33: we have an increase in the defense budget. But back then we had planes that couldn't fly for lack of spare parts or pilots. We had navy vessels that couldn't leave harbor because of lack of crew or
column34: again
column35: lack of spare parts. Today we're well on our way to a 600-ship navy. We have 543 at present.  We have -- our military
column36: the morale is high. I think the people should understand that two-thirds of the defense budget pays for pay and salary
column37: or pay and pension. And then you add to that food and wardrobe
column39: and you only have a small portion going for weapons. But I am determined that if ever our men are called on
column40: they should have the best that we can provide in the manner of tools and weapons. There has been reference to expensive spare parts
column42: we are the ones who found those.  I think we've given the American people back their spirit. I think there's an optimism in the land and a patriotism
column43: and I think that we're in a position once again to heed the words of Thomas Paine
column44: who said: ""We have it in our power to begin the world over again.''

column1: I want to thank the League of Women Voters and the city of Louisville for hosting this evening's debate. I want to thank President Reagan for agreeing to debate. He didn't have to
column3: and we all appreciate it. The President's favorite question is: Are you better off? Well
column4: if you're wealthy
column5: you're better off. If you're middle income
column6: you're about where you were. And if you're modest income
column7: you're worse off. That's what the economists tell us.  But is that really the question that should be asked? Isn't the real question is will we be better off? Will our children be better off? Are we building the future that this nation needs? I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future
column8: not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems
column9: you'll see that we need new leadership.  Are we better of with this arms race? Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens? Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights? Are we better off when we load our children with this fantastic debt? Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children? Can we say
column10: really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?  I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest. I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves. And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare
column11: as the record shows we did
column12: I think that was mean-spirited. When we terminated 400
column13: 000 desperate
column14: hopeless
column15: defenseless Americans who were on disability -- confused and unable to defend themselves
column16: and just laid them out on the street
column17: as we did for 4 years
column18: I don't think that's what America is all about.  America is a fair society
column19: and it is not right that Vice President Bush pays less in taxes than the janitor who helps him. I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.  I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment. And contrary to what the President says
column20: I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful. These laws are not being enforced
column21: have not been enforced
column22: and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price. That's not fair for our future.  I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education
column23: our learning
column24: and our science and training
column25: because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.  I believe in opening doors. We won the Olympics
column26: in part
column27: because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women. I have been for those efforts all my life. The President's record is quite different.  The question is our future. President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments
column28: ""We are great
column29: but we can be greater.'' We can be better if we face our future
column30: rejoice in our strengths
column31: face our problems
column32: and by solving them
column33: build a better society for our children.  Thank you.

column7: you're worse off. That's what the economists tell us.  But is that really the question that should be asked? Isn't the real question is will we be better off? Will our children be better off? Are we building the future that this nation needs? I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future
column8: not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems
column9: you'll see that we need new leadership.  Are we better of with this arms race? Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens? Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights? Are we better off when we load our children with this fantastic debt? Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children? Can we say
column10: really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?  I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest. I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves. And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare

column13: 000 desperate

I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.  I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment. And contrary to what the President says
column20: I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful. These laws are not being enforced
column21: have not been enforced
column22: and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price. That's not fair for our future.  I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education
column23: our learning
column24: and our science and training
column25: because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.  I believe in opening doors. We won the Olympics
column26: in part
column27: because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women. I have been for those efforts all my life. The President's record is quite different.  The question is our future. President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments
